[[Stephen Smith (Australian politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Australian Labor Party politicians, Australian lawyers, Australian ministers for Foreign Affairs, Members of the Australian House of Representatives, Politicians from Western Australia

Stephen Francis Smith (born 12 December 1955) is an Australian politician. He is a member of the Labor Party. He was a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Perth from 1993 to 2013. He was also a minister in the Rudd and Gillard governments, serving as Minister for Foreign Affairs (2007–2010), Minister for Trade (2010) and Minister for Defence (2010–2013).

Smith was born in Narrogin, Western Australia.

[[Federico Castelluccio]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Actors from New Jersey, American movie actors, American television actors, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Naples, People from Paterson, New Jersey

Federico Castelluccio (born April 29, 1964) is an  Italian-born American actor and artist. He is best known for his role as Furio Giunta in the HBO series The Sopranos from 2000 to 2002.

Castelluccio was born in Naples, and moved to the United States at the age of three. He grew up in Paterson, New Jersey. He is married to German actress Yvonne Maria Schäfer. He speaks both Italian and English.

[[Malinae]]

CATEGORIES: Rosaceae

Malinae is a subtribe of plants in the family Rosaceae, tribe Maleae. Members of this subtribe produce fruits known as pomes. Commonly grown members of this tribe include Malus (apples) and Mespilus (medlars).

[[Broad-palmed frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The broad-palmed frog (Litoria latopalmata) is a frog from eastern Australia. It lives in Queensland and New South Wales.

This frog likes to live in forests and woodlands and on flood plains near rivers.  It also lives in billabongs and other permanent and semi-permanent bodies of water.

It lays eggs in groups underwater.  The tadpoles take 50-90 days to become frogs.

[[Yuzu (emulator)]]

CATEGORIES: Nintendo, Software

Yuzu, stylized as yuzu, is a free and open-source emulator of the Nintendo Switch. Yuzu was announced to be in development on January 14, 2018, 10 months after the Nintendo Switch came out. It is developed in C++.

The emulator is made by the developers of the Nintendo 3DS emulator Citra. Both programs use a lot of the same code. At first, Yuzu only supported test programs and homebrew, but as of July 2019, a small amount of games work without any issues. A list of games that work with Yuzu is updated on Yuzu's official website.

[[Millenarianism]]

CATEGORIES: Christian eschatology

Millenarianism is an idea in some religious communities, which refer to a passage in the bible, which says that Jesus will return to earth an establish an empire that will last at least thousand years. Several Christian groups say that this will soon happen, and that the world as we know it is about to change.

[[Caldogno]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Italy, Settlements in Veneto

Caldogno is a town and comune near Vicenza in Italy. It has a population of 11,291.

Famous football player Roberto Baggio was born here.

[[Pigovian tax]]

CATEGORIES: Taxation

A Pigovian tax is a type of tax that takes into account negative effects of things produced. 

This concepts tries to reconcile both the interests of the producer and the social interests of the consumer.

For example, a producer of plastic bottles only cares about their profits, not on the negative effect that the bottles in the trash may have on nature. Other example may be unintended consequences from buildings, or the increase of a need for police in areas where there is more consumption of alcohol.

The concept was studied by economist Arthur Cecil Pigou in his book The Economics of Welfare.

[[Witold Baran]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Polish Olympians, Competitors in athletics, Male athletes

Witold Stanisław Baran (29 July 1939 – 22 June 2020) was a Polish middle-distance runner. He was born in Chmielów, Ostrowiec County. He participated in the 1964 Summer Olympics, however he did not win any medals. He won a silver medal at the 1962 European Athletics Championships.

Baran died on 22 June 2020 in Warsaw at the age of 80.

[[European Athletics Championships]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 establishments in Europe, Biennial athletics competitions, European championships, 1934 in sports

The European Athletics Championships is a biennial (from 2010) athletics event organised by the European Athletics Association. It was first held in 1934 in Turin.

The Championships have taken place every four years, with a few exceptions. Since 2010, they have been organised every two years. However in years where with the Summer Olympics, the marathon and racewalking events are held, the championships are cancelled. 

From 2018, European Championships not held in an Olympic year will form part of the European Championships.

[[Wang Jiamin]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, Living people, Chinese volleyball players

Wang Jiamin (born 11 February 1995) is a Chinese female volleyball player. She was part of the China women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2012 FIVB Women's Club World Championship, 2015 Montreux Volley Masters, and 2017 Asian Women's Club Volleyball Championship. 

She played for the Tianjin Bohai Bank women's volleyball team.

[[Francisco Javier Prado Aránguiz]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from melanoma, Roman Catholics, Bishops, People from Santiago

Francisco Javier Prado Aránguiz (8 March 1929 – 23 June 2020) was a Chilean Roman Catholic bishop. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1953. He was  bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Iquique, Chile, from 1984 to 1988. He then was auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Valparaiso, Chile, from 1988 to 1993 and as bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rancagua, Chile, from 1993 to 2004. He was born in Santiago de Chile.

Prado Aranguaz died from melanoma in Santiago de Chile on 23 June 2020, aged 91.

[[The Third Day]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Jack Smight

The Third Day is a 1965 American suspense thriller movie directed by Jack Smight and based on the novel of the same name by Joseph Hayes. It stars George Peppard, Elizabeth Ashley, Roddy McDowall, Arthur O'Connell, Vincent Gardenia, Robert Webber, Herbert Marshall, Sally Kellerman and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Harry Britt]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Disease-related deaths in California, Democratic socialists, LGBT politicians, Gay men, American LGBT rights activists, Politicians from Texas, Politicians from San Francisco, US Democratic Party politicians

Harry Britt (June 8, 1938 – June 24, 2020) was an American political activist and Democratic politician. He was born in Port Arthur, Texas. 

He was first appointed to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in January 1979 by Mayor Dianne Feinstein, replacing Harvey Milk. Britt was President of the Board of Supervisors from 1989 to 1990. Britt retired in 1993.

Britt ran for the United States House of Representatives for California's 5th congressional district in 1987, running against Nancy Pelosi.

Britt was one of a few members of the Democratic Socialists of America to be elected to public office.

Britt died on June 24, 2020 in San Francisco after a long-illness, aged 82.

[[Accidental Love]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 comedy movies, 2010s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by David O. Russell

Accidental Love is a 2015 movie. It was directed by Stephen Greene. It was based on the book Sammy's Hill. It stars Jessica Biel, Jake Gyllenhaal, Catherine Keener and others.

[[Yuriy Dyachuk-Stavytskyi]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Ukrainian footballers, Ukrainian football managers

Yuriy Dyachuk-Stavytskyi (Юрій Михайлович Дячук-Ставицький; 26 January 1947 – 24 June 2020) was a Ukrainian football manager. He coached following teams FC Bukovyna Chernivtsi, FC Prykarpattya Ivano-Frankivsk, FC Volyn Lutsk, FC Hazovyk Komarne (today's FC Lviv), FC Anzhi Makhachkala, and FC Metalurh Zaporizhia. He was born in Lviv.

Dyachuk-Stavytskyi died on 24 June 2020 in Lviv, aged 73.

[[Sprint football]]

CATEGORIES: Sports in the United States

Sprint football, formerly called lightweight football, is a varsity sport played by United States colleges and universities, under standard American football rules.  The sport is currently governed by the Collegiate Sprint Football League.

In sprint football, players must have a weight of 178 lb (81 kg) or less and a minimum of 5% body fat to be eligible to play.

[[Navy Midshipmen]]

CATEGORIES: Sports in the United States

The Navy Midshipmen are the athletic teams that represent the United States Naval Academy. The academy sponsors 33 varsity sports teams and 12 club sport teams. 

Both men's and women's teams are called Navy Midshipmen or "Mids". 

They participate in the NCAA's Division I.

[[United States Fleet Forces Command]]

CATEGORIES: United States Navy

The United States Fleet Forces Command (USFF) is a service command of the United States Navy that provides naval forces to a wide variety of U.S. forces. 

The naval resources may be given to Combatant Commanders such as United States Northern Command (USNORTHCOM) under the authority of the Secretary of Defense. 

In 2002, the Fleet was made-up over 118,000 Navy and Marine Corps personnel serving on 186 ships and in 1,300 aircraft, with an area of responsibility ranging over most of the Atlantic Ocean from the North Pole to the South Pole, the Caribbean Sea, Gulf of Mexico, and the waters of the Pacific Ocean along the coasts of Central and South America (as far west as the Galapagos Islands).  

The command is based at Naval Support Activity Hampton Roads in Norfolk, Virginia.

[[Chen Xintong]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Chinese volleyball players

Chen Xintong (born 8 April 1994) is a Chinese female volleyball player. She was part of the China women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2012 Asian Junior Women's Volleyball Championship, 2013 FIVB Volleyball Women's U20 World Championship, 2015 Montreux Volley Masters, 2015 Asian Women's U23 Volleyball Championship, 2015 FIVB Volleyball Women's U23 World Championship, 2018 Asian Women's Volleyball Cup, and 2019 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship.

She played for the Tianjin Bohai Bank women's volleyball team and Beijing BAIC Motor women's volleyball team.

[[United States Pacific Fleet]]

CATEGORIES: United States Navy

The United States Pacific Fleet (USPACFLT) is a theater-level component command of the United States Navy, located in the Pacific Ocean. It provides naval forces to the Indo-Pacific Command. 

Fleet headquarters is at Naval Station Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, with large secondary facilities at North Island, San Diego Bay on the Mainland.

[[Lieutenant (junior grade)]]

CATEGORIES: Military ranks

Lieutenant (junior grade), commonly abbreviated as LTJG or, historically, Lt. (j.g.) (as well as variants of both abbreviations), is a junior commissioned officer rank of the United States Navy, the United States Coast Guard, the United States Public Health Service Commissioned Corps, and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Commissioned Officer Corps (NOAA Corps). 

LTJG has a US military  pay grade of O-2. 

The rank is also used in the United States Maritime Service. 

[[Nuclear submarine]]

CATEGORIES: United States Navy

A nuclear submarine is a submarine powered by a nuclear reactor. The large amount of power generated by a nuclear reactor allows nuclear submarines to work at high speed for long periods of time. Current generations of nuclear submarines never need to be refueled throughout their 25-year lifespans. 

[[Octopussy]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s spy movies, 1983 action movies, James Bond movies, Roger Moore, Movies set in Germany, Movies set in India, Movies directed by John Glen

Octopussy is a 1983 British spy action movie directed by John Glen and is the 13th movie in the James Bond franchise. It stars Roger Moore, Maud Adams, Louis Jourdan, Kristina Wayborn, Kabir Bedi, Steven Berkoff, Desmond Llewelyn, Geoffrey Keen, Robert Brown, Lois Maxwell and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Union College]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in New York

Union College is a private liberal arts college in Schenectady, New York. It was founded in 1795. 

In the 19th century, it became the "Mother of Fraternities", as three of the earliest Greek letter societies were created there.  After 175 years as an all-male institution, Union College began enrolling women in 1970.

About 60% of Union students engage in some form of international study or study abroad.

[[United States Navy Reserve]]

CATEGORIES: United States Navy

The United States Navy Reserve (USNR), known as the United States Naval Reserve from 1915 to 2005, is the Reserve Component (RC) of the United States Navy. 

Members of the Navy Reserve, called reservists. They are enrolled in the Selected Reserve (SELRES), the Individual Ready Reserve (IRR), the Full Time Support (FTS), or the Retired Reserve program.

[[Public housing]]

CATEGORIES: Houses

Public housing is a form of housing tenure in which the property is usually owned by a government authority, which may be central or local. Public housing is a form to give homes to poor people or the homeless. 

Social housing is any rental housing that may be owned and managed by the state. Social housing can also be seen as a potential answer to housing inequality.

Private housing is a form of housing tenure in which the property is owned by a private developer.

Nicole Oude Luttikhuis (born 26 December 1997) is a Dutch volleyball player. She was in the Netherlands women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2015 Montreux Volley Masters and 2015 European Games.

[[1936 United States presidential election]]

CATEGORIES: United States presidential campaigns, 1936 in North America, 1930s in the United States

The 1936 United States presidential election was the 38th United States presidential election. It was held on Tuesday, November 3, 1936. The candidates were Democrat Franklin D. Roosevelt, and his running mate John Nance Garner, and Republican Alf Landon of Kansas and his running mate, Frank Knox.

[[Lucinda Williams]]

CATEGORIES: American singer-songwriters, Singers from Nashville, Tennessee, Singers from Louisiana, 1953 births, Living people

Lucinda Williams (born January 26, 1953) is an American singer-songwriter. She recorded her first studio albums during 1978 and 1980. They had traditional country music and blues music style. The albums got little attention from radio, the media and the public.

In 1988, Williams put out her self-titled album. It was named after her. The album had the song "Passionate Kisses". Williams won a Grammy Award for the Best Country Song in 1994.

Williams recorded and put out only one other album, Sweet Old World in late 1992. But in 1998, success came when she put out an album that had a broader scope of songs that blended rock, country, Americana and blues. Off the album, the song "Can't Let Go" was nominated for a Grammy. It is Williams' most successful song so far. The album was marked Gold under the RIAA.

Williams, in 2001, recorded and released the album Essence. It was also successful. One of the album's songs, "Get Right with God", earned Williams a Grammy for Best Female Rock Vocal Performance in 2002.

Williams has won three Grammy and two Americana awards.

[[Cannabis in Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Cannabis, Maryland

In the U.S. state of Maryland, recreational adult use of cannabis, a plant containing psychoactive THC, has been decriminalized and a medical marijuana program is currently established. Since 2014, the possession of 10 grams of cannabis flower or under can have a relatively minor penalty. Those who qualify to use marijuana as a therapy have permission to visit a dispensary, where carefully grown marijuana is sold under the authority of the Maryland government. The regulating government body that oversees the program is known as the "Natalie M. LaPrade Medical Cannabis Commission", or "MMCC". Any and all marijuana products are not covered under any insurance plans and must be paid for in cash only.

Due to the COVID-19 outbreak, the MMCC changed laws and rules surrounding the purchase of medical cannabis to make access easier while implementing social-distancing guidelines, including allowing home-delivery. 

[[Zhongnanhai]]

Zhongnanhai is in the Imperial City which is inside Beijing.

[[Littlejohn's tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

Littlejohn's tree frog or heath frog (Litoria littlejohni) is a frog from Australia. It lives in New South Wales and Victoria. It lives in Western Australia and the Northern Territory.

The male frog grows to 5.0 cm and the female to 7.0 cm.  This frog is light brown with darker marks and a dark band down its back and dark stripes from its nose to its armpits.  It has a lighter belly.  It has orange colouring where its legs meet its body.

This frog lives in forests.  It hides in plants and under dead leaves.

This frog lays eggs in streams and swamps.  The tadpoles live in slow-moving pools with sunlight.

This frog is in danger in New South Wales because human beings change their forests and streams, because of climate change and because introduced species of fish eat their eggs.

[[Litoria lodesdema]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Litoria lodesdema is a frog from New Guinea.

The adult male frog is yellow-green in color and about 2.2 cm long.  It has a bronze or yellow stripe.  These frogs have some webbing on their front feet and more webbing on their hind feet.

They have been seen laying eggs in a roadside marsh.

The scientists who first described (wrote the first formal paper about) Litoria lodesdema named it from the Latin phrase loca demissa septentrionalis domicilium habemus or "in the lowlands of the north we have our home".

[[List of American supercentenarians]]

CATEGORIES: American supercentenarians

American supercentenarians are citizens or residents of the United States who have reached or passed 110 years of age. January 2015, the Gerontology Research Group (GRG) had validated the length of life claims of 782 American supercentenarians. As of date, the GRG lists the oldest living American as Hester Ford (born in Lancaster, South Carolina, August 15, 1905), aged 1905. The longest-lived person ever from the United States was Sarah Knauss, of Hollywood, Pennsylvania, who died on December 30, 1999, aged 119 years, 97 days.

== 100 oldest known Americans == 

Below is a list of the longest lived American supercentenarians according to the GRG.

She played for VK Proton Sarakov and PSK Sakhalin.

[[GMM Grammy]]

CATEGORIES: Record labels

GMM Grammy Public Company Limited (Thai: จีเอ็มเอ็ม แกรมมี่ or G"MM' Grammy) is the largest media conglomerate entertainment company in Thailand. It claims a 70 percent share of the Thai entertainment industry. Grammy artists include Thongchai McIntyre, Silly Fools and Loso. In addition to its music business, the company is involved in concert production, artist management, film and television production and publishing.

[[Long-snouted frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The long-snouted frog, scrub rocket frog or sharp-snouted frog (Litoria longirostris) is a small frog from Australia. It lives on the Cape York Peninsula in northern Queensland.

This frog lives near streams and in forests high above sea level. This frog does not lay its eggs directly in the water.  People have found its eggs on rocks, leaves, dead plants and tree trunks near water but not in it.

[[Nanny state]]

CATEGORIES: Politics, Pejoratives

A nanny state is a term for a government or country with laws that tell people how to behave and how to live their private lives. The reasons may vary. Some may be to protect people's health, or to protect society. It is called paternalism when the government thinks they know better than the people. When someone calls a government a nanny state, they are accusing it of taking away too much of their personal freedom.

[[Disney Princess]]

CATEGORIES: Disney characters, Fictional princesses, Lists of fictional characters, Media franchises, Movie characters, Television characters

Disney Princess is a media franchise by Disney. Its first well-known were Charles Perrault and Brothers Grimm's based two iconic characters introduced Cinderella (1697) and Snow White (1812) respectively, and Walt Disney's feature length animation films including Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937) and Cinderella (1950), which respectively introduced Snow White and Cinderella. The latter studio also gave the company its current name.

It is now a part of Walt Disney Studios, which is owned by The Walt Disney Company.

[[Alberto Santos-Dumont]]

CATEGORIES: 1873 births, 1932 deaths, French aviators, Brazilian people, People with multiple sclerosis

Alberto Santos-Dumont (July 20, 1873 – July 20, 1932) was a Brazilian pilot and early aviator.  He built and flew some of the first airplanes and made some of the first good steering systems for hot air balloons.  He is called the "Father of Aviation" in Brazil.

According to the First Flight Society, he was the third person in the world to fly an airplane, after only Wilbur and Orville Wright.  He was the first person in Europe to fly an airplane. 

[[A9 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A9 is an autoroute (motorway) in France. It goes from the A7 at Orange to the border with Spain at Le Perthus. The autoroute passes Perpignan, Montpellier, and Nimes. The A54 joins onto it towards Marseille. It ends at the A7, which is a link to Lyon and Northern France.

[[Morro Bay, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in San Luis Obispo County, California

Morro Bay is a city in San Luis Obispo County, California. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 10,234.

[[Jesus Dosado]]

CATEGORIES: Filipino people, Bishops, Roman Catholics, 1939 births, 2020 deaths

Jesús Armamento Dosado, C.M. (1 September 1939 – 22 June 2020) was a Filipino Archbishop. He was Archbishop of Ozamiz from 1981 until his retirement in 2016. He was born in Sogod, Cebu. He was ordained priest on 26 May 1966 and became a member of Congregation of the Mission (CM).

Dosado died on 22 June 2020, aged 80.

[[Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Belgium

The Chamber of Representatives (Dutch: Nl-Kamer van Volksvertegenwoordigers.ogg, Chambre des représentants, Abgeordnetenkammer) is one of the two chambers in the bicameral Federal Parliament of Belgium, the other being the Senate. 

It is considered to be the "lower house" of the Federal Parliament.

[[Étienne Cerexhe]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian academics, Belgian judges, Belgian nobility, Jurists, Parti social-chrétien politicians, People from Brussels-Capital Region

Etienne Cerexhe (18 April 1931 – 24 June 2020) was a Belgian judge and academic. He was a member of the Belgian Senate from 1985 to 1987, and the Chamber of Representatives from 1988 to 1991. In 2009, Cerexhe was knighted by King Albert II. Cerexhe was born in Schaerbeek, Belgium.

Cerexhe died on 24 June 2020 at the age of 89.

[[John J. Mooney]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Engineers from New Jersey, American inventors, Scientists from New Jersey

John Joseph Mooney (April 6, 1930 – June 16, 2020) was an American chemical engineer. He was co-inventor of the three-way catalytic converter. His invention helped reduce pollution from motor vehicles since their introduction in the mid-1970s. Mooney was born in Paterson, New Jersey.

Mooney died from stroke-related problems on June 16, 2020 in Wyckoff, New Jersey at the age of 90.

[[Lester Crystal]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Emmy Award winners, American television producers, Journalists from Minnesota, Businesspeople from Minnesota, People from Duluth, Minnesota

Lester M. Crystal (September 13, 1934 – June 24, 2020) was an Emmy Award-winning American television news executive. He was born in Duluth, Minnesota. He was best known for being executive producer of the nation’s first hour-long nightly newscast, The MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour (now known as the PBS Newshour).

He joined the organization as executive producer in 1983 and was appointed president of MacNeil/Lehrer Productions in 2005. He retired from the NewsHour in 2010. He was president of NBC News from 1977 to 1979 and executive producer of NBC Nightly News.

Crystal died on June 24, 2020 in New York City from brain cancer, aged 85.

[[Robert MacNeil]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Canadian journalists, American journalists, American television news anchors, Writers from Montreal

Robert Breckenridge Ware "Robin" MacNeil, OC (born January 19, 1931) is a Canadian-American journalist and writer.  He is a retired television news anchor who partnered with Jim Lehrer to create The MacNeil/Lehrer Report in 1975.

[[Michael Hawley]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, American educators, American pianists, American artists, Writers from California, Writers from New Jersey, Musicians from California, Musicians from New Jersey

Michael Jerome Hawley (November 18, 1961 – June 24, 2020) was an American academic and artist. He worked at MIT’s Media Laboratory where he was a professor and held the Alexander W. Dreyfoos, Jr.. 

Hawley was the founder or co-founder of several major research programs and projects including MIT's GO Expeditions program, Things That Think, Toys of Tomorrow, Counter Intelligence (a culinary research effort), and founder of the nonprofit organization Friendly Planet.  

Hawley was born at Camp Pendleton in California. He died from colon cancer on June 24, 2020 in Cambridge, Massachusetts, aged 58.

[[New Providence, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

New Providence is a borough on the northwestern edge of Union County, New Jersey, United States. It is located on the Passaic River. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population was 12,171.

[[Passaic River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of New Jersey

The Passaic River (p pə) is a river, about 80 mi (129 km) long, in northern New Jersey in the United States.

[[Eddie Kasko]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Boston Red Sox players, Cincinnati Reds players, Houston Astros players, St. Louis Cardinals players, Sportspeople from New Jersey, Sportspeople from Virginia, Businesspeople from New Jersey, Businesspeople from Virginia

Edward Michael Kasko (June 27, 1931 – June 24, 2020) was an American infielder, manager, scout and front office executive. He played for the Major League Baseball. Kasko was born in Elizabeth, New Jersey and raised in nearby Linden.

As a player, he played for the St. Louis Cardinals from 1957 to 1958, Cincinnati Reds from 1959 to 1963, Houston Astros from 1964 to 1965 and the Boston Red Sox in 1966. From 1970 to 1973, he was a manager for the Red Sox.

Kasko died on June 24, 2020 in Richmond, Virginia at the age of 88.

[[John Kennedy Sr. (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Australian rules footballers, Sportspeople from Victoria (Australia)

John Kennedy Sr. (29 December 1928 – 25 June 2020) was an Australian rules footballer. He played for the Hawthorn Football Club, and coached Hawthorn and the North Melbourne Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL). He was born in Camberwell, Victoria.

Kennedy Sr. died on 25 June 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Ionuț Popa]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Romanian footballers, Romanian football managers

Ionuț Popa (17 April 1953 – 25 June 2020) was a Romanian professional footballer and manager. Popa managed teams such as UTA Arad, Bihor Oradea, Politehnica Iași and ACS Poli Timișoara. Popa was born in Săvârşin, Romania.

Popa died on 25 June 2020 in Arad, Romania at the age of 67.

[[Joe Sinnott]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, American comics artists, Artists from New York

Joe Sinnott (ˈ; October 16, 1926 – June 25, 2020) was an American comic book artist. He was best known for his long career with Marvel Comics' Fantastic Four, from 1965 to 1981. During his 60 years with Marvel, he worked on The Avengers, The Defenders and Thor. Sinnott was born in Saugerties, New York.

Sinnott died on June 25, 2020 in Saugerties at the age of 93.

[[Saugerties (village), New York]]

Saugerties (ˈ) is a village in Ulster County, New York, United States. The population was 3,971 at the 2010 census.

[[Gösta Ågren]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Finnish poets

Sven Gösta Ågren (August 3, 1936 – June 24, 2020) was a Finnish author. He won the Finlandia Prize in 1988 for Jär. Ågren wrote his works in Swedish. He was known for his left-wing views.

Ågren died on June 24, 2020, aged 83.

[[Finlandia Prize]]

CATEGORIES: Awards, Finland

The Finlandia Prize (Finlandia-palkinto) is a literary award in Finland by the Finnish Book Foundation. It is awarded annually to the author of the best novel written by a Finnish citizen (Finlandia Award), children's book (Finlandia Junior Award), and non-fiction book (Tieto-Finlandia Award).

[[Sirkka Turkka]]

CATEGORIES: Finnish poets, 1939 births, Living people

Sirkka Turkka (born 2 February 1939) is a Finnish poet. She won the Finlandia Prize in 1987 and the Eino Leino Prize in 2000. 

[[Liisamaija Laaksonen]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Finnish movie actors, Finnish television actors, Finnish stage actors, Finnish screenwriters

Liisamaija Laaksonen-Kaitue (born 6 May 1938) is a Finnish actress. She wrote several television shows in the 1990s and 2000s. Laaksonen was born in Lahti, Finland. She was known for her roles in Helsinki Theatre Academy from 1960 to 1963 and worked as a regular actress of Yle 1963 to 1998.

Laaksonen was known for her roles in Black on White (1968), The Glory and Misery of Human Life (1989), and Kaivo (1992). 

[[Patrice Gélard]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians

Patrice Gélard (3 August 1938 – 25 June 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the Senate of France. He represented the Seine-Maritime. He was a member of the Union for a Popular Movement (UMP) Party.

Gélard died on 25 June 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Lester Grinspoon]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American psychiatrists, American educators, Scientists from Massachusetts, Writers from Massachusetts, People from Newton, Massachusetts

Lester Grinspoon (June 24, 1928 - June 25, 2020) was an American psychiatrist. He was born in Newton, Massachusetts. 

Grinspoon was an Associate Professor of Psychiatry, Emeritus at Harvard Medical School. Grinspoon was senior psychiatrist at the Massachusetts Mental Health Center in Boston, Massachusetts for 40 years. 

Grinspoon was a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the American Psychiatric Association. He was founding editor of The American Psychiatric Association Annual Review and Harvard Mental Health Letter. Grinspoon was editor of Harvard Mental Health Letter for fifteen years.

Grinspoon died on June 25, 2020, one day after his 92nd birthday.

[[2020 Oaxaca earthquake]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 disasters, 2020 in North America, 2020s disasters in North America, 21st century in Mexico, Earthquakes in Mexico, Earthquakes in the 2020s, June 2020 events, Oaxaca

An earthquake struck the Mexican state of Oaxaca at 10:29 local time on June 23, 2020. It was a magnitude of 7.4 w. 

The epicenter was 19 from San Miguel del Puerto and 7.5 south-southwest of Santa María Zapotitlán. The quake was felt by a 49 million people in Mexico and Guatemala. Some tremors were felt as far away as 640. 

Thousands of houses in Oaxaca were damaged and 10 deaths were reported. A tsunami warning was issued for southern Mexico, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras.

[[A10 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A10, also called l’Aquitaine, is the longest autoroute (motorway) in France. It is about 557 long. The autoroute goes from Paris to Bordeaux. It goes past Orleans and Tours. It first opened in 1960. It is part of the European routes E5, E50, E60, and E606.

[[Forbury Gardens]]

CATEGORIES: Parks in the United Kingdom

Forbury Gardens is a public park in the town of Reading in the English county of Berkshire. The park is on the site of the outer court of Reading Abbey. The site was formerly known as the Forbury. The current gardens is still known as The Forbury. Fairs were held on the site three times a year until the 19th century.

On 20 June 2020, three people were killed and three others seriously injured in a mass stabbing at the Forbury Gardens. The incident is being treated as a terrorist incident.

[[Stabbing]]

CATEGORIES: Violence

A stabbing is penetration with a sharp or pointed object at close range. It is a purposeful action, as by an assassin or murderer, but it is also possible to accidentally stab oneself or others. 

Stabbings today are common among gangs and in prisons because knives are cheap.

[[Penetration]]

Penetration may refer to:

[[Penetrating trauma]]

Penetrating trauma is an injury that occurs when an object pierces the skin and enters a tissue of the body, creating an open wound. 

The penetrating object may remain in the tissues, come back out the way it entered, or pass through the tissues and exit from another area. 

An injury in which an object enters the body or a structure and passes all the way through is called a perforating injury, while penetrating trauma implies that the object does not pass through.

[[Dimitri Tito]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, American physicians, People from Washington, D.C., Year of birth missing (living people)

Dimitri Tito is an American osteopathic medical professional and scholar based in Washington, D.C.. In 2019, he was named Outstanding Rural Health Student of the Year by the West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine. Dimitri has been credited to involved with several national organizations that promoted health care in undeserved areas.

[[Barbara Burns]]

CATEGORIES: US Democratic Party politicians, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Barbara A. Burns is a former Democratic member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives and of Pittsburgh City Council.

[[United States Army Rangers]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 establishments in the United States, United States Army

The United States Army Rangers are designated U.S. Army Ranger units, past or present, or are graduates of the U.S. Army Ranger School. The term ranger has been in use unofficially as a military term since the early 17th century. 

[[Mr. Belvedere Rings the Bell]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 comedy movies, American comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Henry Koster

Mr. Belvedere Rings the Bell is a 1951 American comedy movie directed by Henry Koster and is the third and final movie of the series of Lynn Belvedere movies. It stars Joanne Dru, Clifton Webb, Hugh Marlowe, Zero Mostel, Doro Merande and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[A League of Their Own]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s sports movies, 1992 comedy-drama movies, American sports comedy movies, American sports drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Penny Marshall

A League of Their Own is a 1992 American sports comedy-drama movie that is about a fictionalized version of the real-life All-American Girls Professional Baseball League (AAGPBL). 

It was directed by Penny Marshall, the movie stars Tom Hanks, Geena Davis, Madonna, Rosie O'Donnell, and Lori Petty. The screenplay was written by Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel from a story by Kelly Candaele and Kim Wilson.

In 2012, A League of Their Own was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".

[[Lori Petty]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American movie directors, Actors from Tennessee, Actors from Iowa, People from Chattanooga, Tennessee, Actors from Iowa City, Iowa

Lori Petty (born October 14, 1963) is an American actress and director. Her roles include playing Tyler Endicott in the 1991 movie Point Break, Kit Keller in A League of Their Own (1992), Rae Lindley in Free Willy  (1993), and the title role in Tank Girl in 1995. 

[[Hamilton County, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Tennessee counties

Hamilton County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. It is located in the southern part of East Tennessee. As of the 2010 census, the population was 336,463, making it the fourth-most populous county in Tennessee. Its county seat is Chattanooga. The county was named for Alexander Hamilton.

[[Marion County, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Tennessee counties

Marion County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. It is located in East Tennessee. As of the 2010 census, the population was 28,237. Its county seat is Jasper.

[[Jasper, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: County seats in Tennessee, Towns in Tennessee

Jasper is a town in Marion County, Tennessee, United States. It is the county seat of Marion County. The population was 3,279 at the 2010 census.

[[The Eagle Has Landed]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 movies, 1970s adventure movies, 1970s thriller movies, 1970s war movies, British thriller movies, World War II movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by John Sturges

The Eagle Has Landed is a 1976 British World War II adventure thriller movie directed by John Sturges and based on the 1975 novel of the same name by Jack Higgins. It stars Michael Caine, Donald Sutherland, Robert Duvall, Treat Williams, Larry Hagman, Jenny Agutter, Donald Pleasence, Jean Marsh, Anthony Quayle and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Lieutenant Governor of Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Lieutenant Governors of Georgia (U.S. state)

The Lieutenant Governor of Georgia is a constitutional officer of the State of Georgia, elected to a four-year term by popular vote.  The Lieutenant Governor is elected on a separate election from the Georgia Governor.

The office of Lieutenant Governor was created by a state constitutional revision in 1945.  

The current Lieutenant Governor of Georgia is Republican Geoff Duncan.

[[Restructuring]]

CATEGORIES: Legal terms

Restructuring is the corporate management term for the act of reorganizing the legal, ownership, operational, or other structures of a company for the purpose of making it more profitable, or better organized for its present needs. 

Other reasons for restructuring include a change of ownership or ownership structure, demerger, or a response to a crisis or major change in the business such as bankruptcy, repositioning, or buyout. 

Restructuring may also be described as corporate restructuring, debt restructuring and financial restructuring.

[[Mergers and acquisitions]]

CATEGORIES: Legal terms

Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are transactions in which the ownership of companies, other business organizations, or their operating units are transferred or united with other entities.

[[Emílio Garrastazu Médici]]

CATEGORIES: 1905 births, 1985 deaths, Presidents of Brazil, Deaths from renal failure

Emílio Garrastazu Médici (eˈmilju ɡɐʁastaˈzu ˈmɛd(ʒi)si; December 4, 1905 – October 9, 1985) was a Brazilian military leader and politician. He was President of Brazil from 1969 to 1974.

Médici died of kidney failure on October 9, 1985 at the age of 79 after suffering a stroke.

[[Desegregation busing]]

CATEGORIES: Race

Desegregation busing in the United States (also known as simply busing or forced busing) is the practice of assigning and transporting students to schools within or outside their local school districts in an effort to reduce the racial segregation in schools. 

While the 1954 U.S. Supreme Court landmark decision in Brown v. Board of Education declared racial segregation in public schools unconstitutional, many American schools continued to remain largely segregated due to housing inequality. 

[[Flint River (Georgia)]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Georgia (U.S. state)

The Flint River is a 344 river in the U.S. state of Georgia. The river drains 8460 of western Georgia. Along with the Apalachicola and the Chattahoochee rivers, it forms part of the ACF basin. 

[[1972 Democratic National Convention]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 in the United States, 1970s in Florida, United States presidential nominating conventions, United States Democratic Party, July events

The 1972 Democratic National Convention was the presidential nominating convention of the Democratic Party for the 1972 presidential election. It was held at Miami Beach Convention Center in Miami Beach, Florida, on July 10–13, 1972. 

Yvonne Braithwaite Burke was vice-chair, becoming the first African American and the first woman of color to hold that position. 

The convention nominated Senator George McGovern of South Dakota for president and Senator Thomas Eagleton of Missouri for vice president. Eagleton withdrew from the race just 19 days later after it was said that he had previously undergone mental health treatment. He was replaced on the ballot by Sargent Shriver of Maryland, a Kennedy in-law.

[[Social Security Act]]

CATEGORIES: Franklin D. Roosevelt

The Social Security Act of 1935 is a law enacted by the 74th United States Congress and signed into law by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The law created the Social Security program as well as insurance against unemployment. The law was part of Roosevelt's New Deal domestic program.

[[Robert Scheer]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, American radio personalities, American columnists, Journalists from New York City

Robert Scheer (born April 4, 1936) is an American journalist. He was born in New York City. Scheer wrote a column for Truthdig that was nationally syndicated by Creators Syndicate in publications such as The Huffington Post and The Nation. 

He is a clinical professor of communications at the Annenberg School for Communication & Journalism at the University of Southern California. Scheer is editor-in-chief for the Webby Award-winning online magazine Truthdig. 

For many years, he co-hosted the nationally syndicated political analysis radio program Left, Right & Center on National Public Radio (NPR). 

[[Suzana Amaral]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian movie directors, Brazilian screenwriters, People from São Paulo

Suzana Amaral Rezende (March 28, 1932 – June 25, 2020) was a Brazilian movie director and screenwriter. She was best known for directing and writing the 1985 movie Hour of the Star and the 2001 movie Uma Vida em Segredo. Amaral was born in São Paulo, Brazil.

Amaral died at a hospital in São Paulo on June 25, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[The Model and the Marriage Broker]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 comedy movies, 1950s romance movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by George Cukor

The Model and the Marriage Broker is a 1951 American romantic comedy movie directed by George Cukor and starring Jeanne Crain, Scott Brady, Thelma Ritter, Zero Mostel, Michael O'Shea, Helen Ford, Frank Fontaine. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1952.

[[The Lion Sleeps Tonight]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 songs

"The Lion Sleeps Tonight" is a song originally written and recorded by Solomon Linda under the title "Mbube" for the South African Gallo Record Company in 1939. Linda's original was written in Zulu, while the English version's lyrics were written by George David Weiss. 

The song was covered internationally by many pop and folk revival artists in the 1950s and 1960s, including Henri Salvador, the Weavers, Jimmy Dorsey, Yma Sumac, Miriam Makeba, and the Kingston Trio. 

In 1961, it became a number one hit in the United States as adapted in English with the best-known version by the doo-wop group the Tokens. 

[[Cardwell, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Montana, Census-designated places in Montana

Cardwell is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) in Jefferson County, Montana, United States. The population was 50 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Helena Micropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Big Sky, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Montana, Unincorporated communities in Montana

Big Sky is a census-designated place (CDP) in Gallatin and Madison counties in southwestern Montana. As of the 2010 census it had a population of 2,308. It is 45 southwest of Bozeman. 

[[Chet Huntley]]

CATEGORIES: Deaths from lung cancer, American television news anchors, 1911 births, 1974 deaths, Writers from Montana

Chester Robert "Chet" Huntley (December 10, 1911 – March 20, 1974) was an American television newscaster. He was best known for co-anchoring NBC's evening news program, The Huntley–Brinkley Report, for 14 years beginning in 1956.

Huntley died of lung cancer on March 20, 1974, at his home in Big Sky at the age of 62.

In 1988, Huntley was posthumously honored into the Television Hall of Fame.

[[David Brinkley]]

CATEGORIES: American television news anchors, American war correspondents, 1920 births, 2003 deaths, American autobiographers, American political writers, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, Emmy Award winners, Writers from North Carolina, Writers from Washington, D.C.

David McClure Brinkley (July 10, 1920 – June 11, 2003) was an American newscaster for NBC and ABC in a career lasting from 1943 to 1997.

From 1956 through 1970, he co-anchored NBC's top-rated nightly news program, The Huntley–Brinkley Report, with Chet Huntley.

In the 1980s and 1990s, Brinkley was host of the popular Sunday This Week with David Brinkley program and a top commentator on election-night coverage for ABC News. 

Brinkley received ten Emmy Awards, three George Foster Peabody Awards, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

He wrote three books, including the 1988 bestseller Washington Goes to War.

[[Catskill Park]]

CATEGORIES: Parks in the United States, Geography of New York

The Catskill Park is in the Catskill Mountains in New York in the United States. It is made up of 700,000 of land inside in four counties: Delaware, Greene, Sullivan, and Ulster.  As of 2005, 287,500 or 41 percent of the land within, is owned by the state as part of the Forest Preserve. Another 5% is owned by New York City.

[[Catskill Mountains]]

CATEGORIES: Mountains of the United States, Appalachian Mountains

The Catskill Mountains, also known as the Catskills, are part of the larger Appalachian Mountains. They are in southeastern New York.  The Catskills are generally defined as those areas close to or within the borders of the Catskill Park, a 700000 forest preserve forever protected from many forms of development under New York state law.

The Catskills form the northeastern end of the Allegheny Plateau (also known as the Appalachian Plateau).

[[Phoenicia, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in New York (state), Hamlets in New York

Phoenicia is a hamlet (and census-designated place) of Shandaken in Ulster County, New York, United States. The population was 309 at the 2010 census.

It is seen as one of the best vacation towns in the greater New York City area.

[[Shandaken, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Shandaken is a town on the northern border of Ulster County, New York, United States, northwest of Kingston, New York.  As of the 2010 census, the town had a total population of 3,085.

[[Delhi (village), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York, County seats in New York

Delhi (ˈ DEL) is a village in Delaware County, New York, United States. The population was 3,087 at the 2010 census. Delhi is the county seat of Delaware County.

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York, County seats in New York

Catskill is a village in Greene County, New York, United States. The population was 4,081 at the 2010 census. The village is in the northeast part of the town of Catskill. Catskill is the county seat of Greene County.

[[Catskill (town), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Catskill is a town in the southeast part of Greene County, New York, United States. The population was 11,775 at the 2010 census. 

[[Monticello, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York, County seats in New York

Monticello (ˌ MON) is a village located in Thompson in Sullivan County, New York, United States. The population was 6,726 at the 2010 census. It is the seat for the Town of Thompson and the county seat of Sullivan County. The village was named after the residence of Thomas Jefferson.

[[Thompson, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Thompson is a town in southern part of Sullivan County, New York, United States. The population was 15,308 at the 2010 census.

[[County Fermanagh]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Northern Ireland

County Fermanagh (f fər; Fir Manach or Fear Manach) is one of the thirty-two counties of Ireland and one of the six counties of Northern Ireland. The county covers an area of 1,691 km² (653 sq mi) and has a population of 61,805 as of 2011. Enniskillen is the county town.

[[Enniskillen]]

CATEGORIES: County towns in Northern Ireland

Enniskillen (ˌ, from Inis Ceithleann ', 'Ceithlenn's island') is a town and civil parish in County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland. It had a population of 13,823 at the 2011 Census. It was the seat of local government for the former Fermanagh District Council, and is the county town of Fermanagh as well as its largest town.

In 1987, a Provisional Irish Republican Army bombing killed 12 people.

[[County Londonderry]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Northern Ireland

 County Londonderry (Contae Dhoire; Ulster-Scots: Coontie Lunnonderrie), also known as County Derry, is one of the six counties of Northern Ireland. The county covers an area of 2,074 km² (801 sq mi) and today has a population of about 247,132.

[[Downpatrick]]

CATEGORIES: County towns in Northern Ireland, County Down

Downpatrick (Dún Pádraig) is a small town about 21 south of Belfast in County Down, Northern Ireland. Its cathedral is said to be the burial place of Saint Patrick. 

Downpatrick had a population of 10,822 according to the 2011 Census.

[[Armagh]]

CATEGORIES: County towns in Northern Ireland, County Armagh

Armagh (ɑr ar; Ard Mhacha, ˌaɾd̪ˠ ˈwaxə, "Macha's height") is the county town of County Armagh and a city in Northern Ireland, as well as a civil parish.

[[Antrim, County Antrim]]

CATEGORIES: County towns in Northern Ireland, Settlements in County Antrim

Antrim (Aontroim, ') is a town and civil parish in County Antrim in the northeast of Northern Ireland. It had a population of 23,375 people in the 2011 Census.

[[Qinghai Lake]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of China

The Qinghai Lake, or Ch'inghai Lake, is the largest lake in China. It is in the Qinghai Province, which is where the lake gets its name. The lake has a surface area of 4186. The lake is a alkaline salt lake. Its size has changed over time. During the 20th century, it became smaller, but has been getting larger since 2004. The average depth of the lake was 21 in 2008. The deepest part of the lake was 25.5.

[[Caldwell, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

Caldwell is a borough located in northwestern Essex County, New Jersey, about 16 outside of New York City and 6 miles west of Newark. From the 2010 United States Census, 7,822 lived here.

[[Munawar Hasan]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Pakistan, Pakistani politicians

Syed Munawar Hasan (سید منور حسن; (5 August 1941– 26 June 2020) was a Pakistani politician. He was the Ameer (President) of Islamist party Jamaat-e-Islami, Pakistan from 2009 to 2014. He was born in Delhi, British India. 

In late March 2014, Hasan became the first sitting emir or head in the history of JI to be voted out of office when Siraj-ul-Haq Khan was elected Ameer by the Jamaat Arakeen (JI members with voting rights).

Hasan died at a hospital in Karachi from COVID-19 on 26 June 2020, aged 78.

Mika Yoshida (吉田美香) is a Japanese professional Go player at Kansai Ki-in, Osaka. She is known as one of the most strongest player from Osaka in the 1990s through the 2000s.

[[Kazuko Konishi]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Japanese Go players, People from Osaka, Living people

Kazuko Konishi is a Japanese professional Go player at Kansai Ki-in, Osaka. She is known as one of the strongest female Go player in the Kansai region.

She played at the 2013 European Cup.

[[Santos-Dumont 14-bis]]

CATEGORIES: Aircraft, Aviation

italictitlethumb|right|The Santos-Dumont 14-bis.

The Santos-Dumont 14-bis was a biplane invented in the early 1900s by Alberto Santos-Dumont.  In the fall of 1906, it became the first airplane to fly in Europe.

Santos-Dumont tried several times before he truly managed to fly in the 14-bis.  His first attempt in July 1906 did not work.  In September, he managed two short hops.  In October, the 14-bis flew for 50 meters.  That was the first flight that the Aero Club of France ever officially witnessed.  In November, he was able to keep the 14-bis in the air for 220 meters, 6 meters up in the air.

According to the Aero Club of France, the 14-bis was 40 feet wide from wingtip to wingtip, 33 feet wide, and weighed 352 pounds.  It used an Antoinette engine.  It was made out of pine and and bamboo with aluminum to keep it together.  Its wings were made out of silk cloth. 

The 14-bis had three different sets of controls so Alberto Santos-Dumont could steer.  Some were tied to his shoulders so that he looked like he was dancing or shaking while in the air.

No one knows where the original 14-bis from the fall of 1906 is now.  Experts think Santos-Dumont took it apart and used the pieces to build other airplanes.

Some people, especially in Brazil, believe the 14-bis was the first airplane to fly, before the Wright Brothers' Flyer.  The main reason for this is that although the Wright Brothers flew the Flyer at Kitty Hawk in 1903, they did not tell many people about it right away.  Europeans saw Alberto Santos-Dumont fly the 14-bis in 1906 before they heard about the Wrights flying the Flyer in 1903.  This was because the Wright Brothers hoped to patent their work and make money, so they kept most of their experiments a secret.  Alberto Santos Dumont was not trying to make money, so he invited almost anyone who wanted to come watch him work.  However, the Wright Brothers did invite witnesses to their first flight at Kitty Hawk in 1903 to watch and take a photograph.  By 1906, the Wright Brothers had flown many of their planes many times, for as far as 39 kilometers. Today, most aviation historians believe that the 14-bis was not the first plane to fly.

[[Nantwich]]

CATEGORIES: Market towns in England, Civil parishes in England, Towns in Cheshire

Nantwich is a market town and civil parish in the ceremonial county of Cheshire, England.  It is known for having one of the highest numbers of listed buildings in England, with Tudor and Georgian architecture. In 2011, the town had a population of 17,424.

The town is around 4 south-west of the railway town of Crewe and 20 miles south-east of the city of Chester. It is on the Cheshire Plain, on the banks of the River Weaver. The Shropshire Union Canal runs to the west of the town.

The origins of the settlement date to Roman times, when salt from Nantwich was used by the Roman garrisons at Chester and Stoke-on-Trent as a preservative and a condiment.

[[Sure We Can]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 establishments in the United States, Non-profit organizations of New York

Sure We Can is a non-profit redemption center in Brooklyn, New York. In 2019, the center redeemed 10 million cans and bottles.

Sure We Can was founded in 2007, by Ana Martinez de Luco and Eugene Gadsden.

The organization also serves the community on environmental and sustainability issues, producing and delivering compost.

[[Alan Walker]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, British DJs, British musicians, British record producers, Living people, Norwegian people

Alan Walker (born 24 August 1997) is a British-Norwegian music producer. He is best known for his song "Faded." The song got good ratings worldwide and became a platinum single in 14 countries. The magazine DJ Mag said Walker was 27th on their Top 100 DJs list of 2019.

In 2018, he released his music album Different Worlds.

[[MacOS High Sierra]]

macOS High Sierra (version 10.13) is the fourteenth major release of macOS, Apple Inc.'s desktop operating system for Macintosh computers. macOS High Sierra was announced at the Apple Worldwide Developers Conference on June 5, 2017 and was released on September 25, 2017. The name "High Sierra" refers to the High Sierra region in California. Like with Snow Leopard, Mountain Lion, and El Capitan, the name also suggests to its status as a better version of its older version, focused on performance improvements rather than user features.

[[Bernay-Neuvy-en-Champagne]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 establishments in France, Communes in Sarthe

Bernay-Neuvy-en-Champagne is a commune. It is found in the Pays de la Loire region in the Sarthe department in the west of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Neuvy-en-Champagne (the seat) and Bernay-en-Champagne.

[[Locmaria-Plouzané]]

Locmaria-Plouzané (Lokmaria-Plouzane) is a commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France.

[[Loir en Vallée]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Sarthe

Loir en Vallée is a commune. It is found in the Pays de la Loire region in the Sarthe department in the west of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Ruillé-sur-Loir (the seat), La Chapelle-Gaugain, Lavenay and Poncé-sur-le-Loir.

[[Boké Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

thumb|Location of the Boké Region in GuineaRedlinks

Boké is a region in the west of Guinea. It is bordered by the countries of Senegal and Guinea-Bissau and the Guinean regions of Kindia and Labé. The regional capital is the city of Boké. As of the 2014 census, 1,083,147 people lived there. It has an area of 31.186.

[[Kindia Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

Kindia is a region in the west of Guinea. It is bordered by the country of Sierra Leone and the Guinean regions of Conakry, Labé, Mamou, and Boké. The regional capital is the city of Kindia. As of the 2014 census, 1,561,374 people lived there. It has an area of 28.873.

[[Bokksu]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 establishments in the United States

Bokksu is an American subscription service that sends subscribers local Japanese snacks and candies. It was founded by  Danny Taing.

[[Jen Crouse]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, American rugby union players

Jen Crouse (born 1988) is an American rugby union player. She was named 2004 USA Women's Rugby Player of the Year, and a Women’s Rugby Player of the Decade.  She played for the United States women's national rugby union team at the 2006 Women's Rugby World Cup. 

She played for University of Connecticut. 

[[Conakry Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

Conakry is a region in the west of Guinea. It is bordered by the Guinean region of Kindia and the Atlantic Ocean. The regional capital is the city of Conakry, which is also the national capital. As of the 2017 census, 2,317,376 people lived there. It has an area of 450.

Erin Carter is an American rugby union player. She played for the United States women's national rugby union team at the 2006 Women's Rugby World Cup.

[[Faranah Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

Faranah is a region in east-central Guinea. It is bordered by the countries of Sierra Leone and Mali and the Guinean regions of Kankan, Mamou, Nzérékoré, and Labé. The regional capital is the town of Faranah. As of the 2014 census,

942,733 people lived there. It has an area of 35.581.

[[Merano]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol

Merano (Meran, Maran) is a city in Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol in northern Italy. In 2019, 41,172 people lived there.

Lamar County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 18,317 people lived there. The county seat is Barnesville.

Wrightsville is a city in Johnson County, Georgia, United States. The population was 2,195 at the 2010 census. The city is the county seat of Johnson County.

Barnesville is a city in Lamar County, Georgia, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 6,755. The city is the county seat of Lamar County.

[[Kristin Baja]]

Kristin Baja is an American rugby union player and rugby sevens player. She played for the United States women's national rugby union team at the 2006 Women's Rugby World Cup. 2002 Hong Kong Women's Sevens, and 2006 Hong Kong Women's Sevens.

[[Josef Smolka]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Czech volleyball players, Olympic bronze medalists

Josef Smolka (22 March 1939 – 1 June 2020) was a Czech volleyball player. He competed for Czechoslovakia in the 1968 Summer Olympics. He was born in Troubky, Přerov District. In 1968 he was part of the Czechoslovak team which won the bronze medal in the Olympic tournament. He played seven matches.

Smolka died on 1 June 2020, aged 81.

[[Springfield, Georgia]]

Douglas is a city in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is the county seat of Coffee County.

[[Nigel Weiss]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, South African scientists, Astronomers, Mathematicians

Nigel Oscar Weiss FRS (16 December 1936 – 24 June 2020) was a South African astronomer and mathematician. He was a leader in the field of astrophysical and geophysical fluid dynamics. He was Emeritus Professor of Mathematical Astrophysics at the University of Cambridge. Between 2000 and 2002 he was President of the Royal Astronomical Society.

Weiss died on 24 June 2020, aged 83.

[[Chino, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in San Bernardino County, California

[[Huey (rapper)]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, 2020 deaths, Murders by firearm in the United States, American hip hop musicians, American rap musicians from Missouri, Musicians from St. Louis, Missouri, Singers from St. Louis, Missouri

Lawrence Franks Jr. (September 12, 1987 – June 25, 2020) better known by his stage name Huey, was an American rapper. At first, he signed to Jive Records. Franks was best known for his 2006 debut single, "Pop, Lock & Drop It". Huey was born in Kinloch, Missouri.

Huey was shot and killed on June 25, 2020 in Kinloch, aged 32.

[[Kinloch, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

Kinloch is a city in St. Louis County, Missouri, United States. The population was 298 as of the 2010 census.

[[Hans Sleutelaar]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Translators, Writers from Rotterdam

Hans Sleutelaar (22 September 1935 – 25 June 2020) was a Dutch poet. Together with Cornelis Bastiaan Vaandrager and Hans Verhagen, Sleutelaar was one of the Zestigers (Nederlandse literatuur), a Dutch term talking about the literary movement in the 1960s. Together with Eelke de Jong, Sleutelaar collected 500 fairytales in the collection Sprookjes van de Lage Landen.

Among other things, Sleutelaar worked as a junior copywriter at Unilever, as a freelance copywriter, as a Haagse Post employee and as editor-in-chief of publisher Boelen. He had his own publishing company from 1985 to 2000. 

Sleutelaar died on 25 June 2020 in Rotterdam, aged 84.

[[Maya Ulanovskaya]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, American political activists, Writers from Moscow, Writers from New York City, Naturalized citizens of Israel, American educators, Israeli writers, Israeli academics, Russian translators

Maya Ulanovskaya (October 20, 1932 – June 25, 2020) was an American-born Russian-Israeli translator, writer and activist. Along with her husband, Anatoly Yakobson, were key figures in the dissident movement in the USSR. In the 1960s - 1970s, Ulanovskaya worked at the Institute of Scientific Information on Social Sciences of the Russian Academy of Sciences (INION RAN) library in Moscow.

[[Jacqui Stewart]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Living people, New Zealand rugby union players

Jacqui Stewart (nee Apiata, born 10 June 1966) was a New Zealand rugby union player. She played for the New Zealand women's national rugby union team at the 1991 Women's Rugby World Cup.

She grew up in Otautau. She studied at Central Southland College, and University of Canterbury.

[[Gnomeo & Juliet]]

CATEGORIES: 2011 romance movies, 2011 comedy movies, 2010s romantic comedy movies, 2010s fantasy movies, 2011 animated movies, British romantic comedy movies, British fantasy movies, British animated movies, American romantic comedy movies, American fantasy movies, American animated movies, Movies directed by Kelly Asbury

Gnomeo & Juliet is a 2011 British-American 3D computer-animated fantasy romantic comedy movie loosely based on William Shakespeare's play Romeo and Juliet and an original screenplay by John R. Smith and Rob Sprackling. The movie had funding from Disney and released through its Touchstone Pictures banner. 

It was co-written and directed by Kelly Asbury and starring the voices of James McAvoy, Emily Blunt, Michael Caine, Jason Statham, Maggie Smith, Patrick Stewart, Jim Cummings, Ashley Jensen, Stephen Merchant, Matt Lucas, and Ozzy Osbourne.

The movie premiered at the El Capitan Theatre in Hollywood on January 23, 2011. It was theatrically released in the United Kingdom and United States on February 11, 2011.

[[16th Street Baptist Church bombing]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 in the United States

The 16th Street Baptist Church bombing was an act of white supremacist terrorism which happened at the African-American 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama, on Sunday, September 15, 1963. Three 14-year-old girls and an 11-year-old girl were killed.

Four members of a local Ku Klux Klan chapter planted at least 15 sticks of dynamite beneath the steps located on the east side of the church.

Although the FBI had concluded in 1965 that the 16th Street Baptist Church bombing had been committed by four known Klansmen and segregationists: Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr., Herman Frank Cash, Robert Edward Chambliss, and Bobby Frank Cherry, no prosecutions were conducted until 1977.

[[Iyo ang Tondo Kanya ang Cavite]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 action movies, Filipino movies

Iyo ang Tondo Kanya ang Cavite (Tondo is Yours, Cavite is His) is a 1986 Filipino action movie directed by Pablo Santiago and stars Fernando Poe Jr., Ramon Revilla Sr., Anita Linda, Liza Lorena, Parquito Diaz, Berting Labra, Ruel Vernal, Romy Diaz, Vic Diaz, Max Alvarado. It was distributed by BSH Films.

[[Kathleen Wilton]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing (living people), Living people, New Zealand rugby union players

Kathleen Wilton was a New Zealand rugby union player. She played for the New Zealand women's national rugby union team at the 2014 Women's Rugby World Cup.

She studied at University of Otago. She played for Alhambra Union Rugby Football Club and Eketahuna (WB).

[[Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from natural causes in the United States, American terrorists, American people convicted of manslaughter, American murderers, People from Birmingham, Alabama

Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr. (June 20, 1938 – June 26, 2020) was an American terrorist and convicted felon. At the time of his death, he was serving a life sentence for his role in the 16th Street Baptist Church bombing in Birmingham, Alabama in 1963, which killed four young African-American girls (Carole Robertson, Cynthia Wesley, Addie Mae Collins, and Denise McNair). 

Blanton was the son of Thomas Edwin "Pops" Blanton Sr., who was a known racist in the Birmingham, Alabama area, and his wife.

On June 26, 2020, Blanton died at William E. Donaldson Correctional Facility in Bessemer, Alabama of natural causes while serving his life sentence. He was 82 years old.

[[Kelly Asbury]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stomach cancer, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, American animators, American voice actors, American illustrators, American children's writers, American screenwriters, Writers from Texas, Movie directors from Texas, Actors from Texas, People from Beaumont, Texas

Kelly Adam Asbury (January 15, 1960 – June 26, 2020) was an American animated movie director, screenwriter, voice actor, published children's book author/illustrator, and non-fiction author. He was best known for directing animated movies including Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron, Shrek 2 and Gnomeo & Juliet. He was born in Beaumont, Texas.

Asbury died from stage 4 abdominal cancer at his home in Encino, California on June 26, 2020 at the age of 60.

[[Hermes Binner]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Physicians, Deaths from pneumonia, Mayors, Argentine politicians

Hermes Juan Binner (June 5, 1943 − June 26, 2020) was an Argentine physician and a politician. He was Governor of Santa Fe from 2007 to 2011. Binner is the first Socialist to become the governor of an Argentine province. From 1995 to 2003, he was Mayor of Rosario, Argentina.

He unsuccessfully ran for President of Argentina in 2011, losing to Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.

On June 26, 2020, Binner died from pneumonia at a hospital in Casilda at the age of 77.

[[James Dunn (theologian)]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, British educators, Theologians

James Douglas Grant Dunn GBR (21 October 1939 – 26 June 2020), also known as Jimmy Dunn, was a British New Testament scholar. For many years, he was the Lightfoot Professor of Divinity in the Department of Theology at the University of Durham. He worked broadly within the Protestant tradition.

Dunn died on 26 June 2020, aged 80.

[[William Negri]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Italian footballers, Italian football managers

William Negri (ˈwilljam ˈneːɡri; 30 July 1935 – 26 June 2020) was an Italian association football manager and footballer. He played as a goalkeeper. He represented the Italy national football team 12 times. He was born in Bagnolo San Vito, Italy.

Negri died on 26 June 2020 in Mantua, Italy at the age of 84.

[[Tony Pidgley]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, English businesspeople, People from Surrey

Anthony William Pidgley CBE (6 August 1947 – 26 June 2020) was an English businessman. He was the founder and chairman of Berkeley Group Holdings, one of the UK's largest housebuilding businesses. According to The Sunday Times Rich List in 2019, Pidgley was worth £335 million. He was born in Surrey, England.

Pidgley died on 26 June 2020, aged 72.

[[Litoria megalops]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Animals of Asia, Frogs

Litoria megalops is a frog from Indonesia. Scientists saw it on the western half of the island of New Guinea, in Indonesia's Papua Province.  It is related to L. becki, L. micromembrana and L. modica.

Male adult frogs are about 2.7 to 2.8 cm long and females are 3.2 to 3.6 cm long.  This frog has very large eyes for its size, which is why scientists named it megalops, which means large eyes.  Its front feet are not webbed, but its hind feet are.  It has teeth on its upper jaw.  Some of the frogs are the yellow-brown color of amber with a green mark over each eye and a green stripe on the body, and some are bright orange in color.  

Scientists found this frog living 1070 meters above sea level.  It was found only in the fast-flowing parts of the Wapona River, so they call it a torrent-dwlling frog.  The scientists checked slow-flowing streams nearby and saw that this frog did not live in them. 

This frog has clear eggs.  It lays its eggs underneath rocks at the bottoms of streams.  The tadpoles have flattened bodies and suckers on their mouths.

[[Ramon Revilla Sr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Filipino actors, Filipino politicians, Deaths from heart failure

José Acuña Bautista Sr., popularly known as Ramon Revilla Sr. or simply Ramon Revilla (March 8, 1927 – June 26, 2020), was a Filipino actor and politician. He was Senator from 1992 to 2004. Revilla Sr. was a member of the Lakas. He was born in Imus, Cavite. 

An actor, he was best known for his roles in Iyo ang Tondo Kanya ang Cavite, Arrest: Pat. Rizal Alih – Zamboanga Massacre and Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom.

Revilla Sr. died from heart failure on June 26, 2020 in Manila, aged 93.

[[Julianus Kemo Sunarko]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian people, Bishops, Roman Catholics

Julianus Kemo Sunarko S.J. (25 December 1941 – 26 June 2020) was an Indonesian Roman Catholic bishop. He was the bishop emeritus of the diocese of Purwokerto. He was born in Sleman Regency. Sunarko was Bishop of Purwokerto from 2000 to 2016.

Sunarko died on 26 June 2020 at a hospital in Semarang, aged 78.

[[The Descent]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 movies, 2005 horror movies, 2000s thriller movies, 2000s adventure movies, British horror movies, British thriller movies, British adventure movies

The Descent is a 2005 British adventure horror thriller movie written and directed by Neil Marshall. The movie follows six women who, having entered a cave system, struggle to survive against the humanoid creatures inside.

The Descent opened in cinemas in the United Kingdom on 8 July 2005. It premiered in the 2006 Sundance Film Festival and released on 4 August 2006 in the United States. The movie received positive reviews.

[[Juan Ostoic]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Chilean people, Basketball players, Olympians

Juan Benito Ostoic Ostoic (21 March 1931 – 25 June 2020), known as Juan Ostoic, was a Chilean basketball player. He competed in the men's tournament at the 1952 Summer Olympics and the 1956 Summer Olympics.

Ostoic also created crossword puzzles for the La Tercera newspaper since 1981 under the pseudonym "Jota O".

Ostoic was born in Huara, Chile. He died on 25 June 2020 from heart failure in Santiago de Chile, aged 89.

[[Jules Bass]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, American composers, American television directors, American television producers, American television writers, Movie directors from Pennsylvania, Movie producers from Pennsylvania, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Businesspeople from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Jules Bass (born September 16, 1935) is an American director, producer, composer, lyricist, and author. He co-founded a film production company in New York. He joined ASCAP in 1963. He was known for his work with Arthur Rankin Jr. in directing The Year Without a Santa Claus. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

[[Jay Silverheels]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 1980 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Canadian stage actors, Canadian voice actors, Competitors in athletics, Canadian poets, Stuntmen, Writers from Ontario, Sportspeople from Ontario, Actors from Ontario

Jay Silverheels (born Harold Jay Smith, May 26, 1912 – March 5, 1980) was an Aboriginal Canadian actor and athlete. He was well known for his role as Tonto, the Native American sidekick of the Lone Ranger in the American western television series The Lone Ranger.

[[Jacob Grimm]]

CATEGORIES: 1785 births, 1863 deaths, German writers, German scientists

Jacob Ludwig Karl Grimm (4 January 1785 – 20 September 1863), also known as Ludwig Karl, was a German philologist, jurist, and mythologist. He is known as the discoverer of Grimm's law of linguistics. He was the co-author of the Deutsches Wörterbuch, the author of Deutsche Mythologie, and the editor of Grimm's Fairy Tales. 

He was the older brother of Wilhelm Grimm, of the literary duo the Brothers Grimm.

Jacob Grimm died on 20 September 1863, in Berlin, Germany from disease

[[Wilhelm Grimm]]

CATEGORIES: 1786 births, 1859 deaths, German writers, German scientists, European anthropologists

Wilhelm Carl Grimm (also Karl;

 24 February 1786snd16 December 1859) was a German author and anthropologist. He was the younger brother of Jacob Grimm, of the literary duo the Brothers Grimm.

From 1837 to 1841, the Grimm brothers joined five of their colleague professors at the University of Göttingen to form a group known as the Göttinger Sieben (The Göttingen Seven). They protested against Ernest Augustus, King of Hanover.

[[Angels in the Outfield (1951 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Clarence Brown

Angels in the Outfield is a 1951 American family comedy movie directed by Clarence Brown and starring Paul Douglas, Janet Leigh, Keenan Wynn, Donna Corcoran, Lewis Stone, Bruce Bennett, Marvin Kaplan, Ellen Corby. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and was remade in 1994.

[[Striped rocket frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The striped rocket frog, streamlined rocket frog, Australian rocket frog or rocket frog (Litoria nasuta) is a frog from Australia and the island of New Guinea.

This frog can grow to 4.5 cm in size. It has a long body and a pointed nose and only a little webbing on its feet.  It is brown with black stripes and other black marks.  It has ridges on its back.

This frog lives on the ground in tropical forests and in streams, swamps and ponds.  It lives in the southern part of the island of New Guinea, in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea.  It lives all across the northern and eastern coasts of Australia and people have seen it as far south as Sydney.  It is known for being able to jump very far.  It has longer cartilage in its toes than most frogs have, which may be why it jumps so well. This frog can jump 4 metres (>12 feet).

This frog lays 50-100 eggs at a time.  The females lay eggs in groups that float on top of the water.  Tadpoles can grow into frogs in 6 months.

[[Enter Laughing (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on books, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Carl Reiner

Enter Laughing is a 1967 American comedy movie directed by first time director Carl Reiner and based on the autobiographical novel and play of the same name. It stars Jose Ferrer, Shelley Winters, Elaine May, Jack Gilford, Janet Margolin, Rob Reiner, Nancy Kovack, Michael J. Pollard, Don Rickles and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

Sarah Ulmer (born 24 April 1977 in Regina) is a Canadian rugby union player. She played for the Canada women's national rugby union team at the 2002 Women's Rugby World Cup, 2006 Women's Rugby World Cup, and 2010 Women's Rugby World Cup.
