[[Zoolander]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 comedy movies, 2000s action comedy movies, American action comedy movies, Impact of the September 11 attacks

Zoolander is a 2001 American action comedy movie directed by Ben Stiller and starring Stiller, Owen Wilson and Will Ferrell. The movie is based on many short movies directed by Russell Bates and written by Drake Sather and Stiller for the VH1 Fashion Awards television specials in 1996 and 1997. 

It was a satire on the fashion industry. The movie received mixed to positive reviews from critics but was a box office success.  A sequel, Zoolander 2, was released in February 2016. 

[[Stuart Cornfeld]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from California, Movie producers from California

Stuart Cornfeld (November 15, 1952 – June 26, 2020) was an American movie producer, and actor. He was business partners with Ben Stiller in the company, Red Hour Productions. He was born in Tarzana, California. He was known for producing Zoolander, Tropic Thunder and DodgeBall: A True Underdog Story.

Cornfeld died on June 26, 2020 from cancer at the age of 67.

[[Claudine (movie)]]

Claudine is a 1974 American romantic comedy-drama movie directed by John Berry and starring James Earl Jones, Diahann Carroll in her Oscar nominated role, Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs, Roxie Roker. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Pendulum (movie)]]

Pendulum is a 1969 American thriller movie directed by George Schaefer. It stars George Peppard, Jean Seberg, Richard Kiley, Charles McGraw, Madeleine Sherwood and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Airport 1975]]

[[Paula White]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Living people, Television evangelists, People from Florida, People from Mississippi, Christian clergy, American television talk show hosts, People from Tupelo, Mississippi, American theologians, Religious leaders

Paula Michelle White-Cain (née Furr; April 20, 1966) is an American preacher, author, televangelist and exponent of  prosperity theology, a controversial religious belief that assumes that material prosperity is a proof of God's grace. 

White became chair of the evangelical advisory board in Donald Trump's administration. In November 2019, Trump appointed White as special advisor to the Faith and Opportunity Initiative at the Office of Public Liaison.

From 2014 until May 2019, she was senior pastor of New Destiny Christian Center, in Apopka, Florida, a non-denominational, multicultural megachurch. She was formerly the co-pastor of Without Walls International Church in Tampa, Florida, a church she co-founded with pastor and then-husband Randy White in 1991.

She was listed number three on the "50 Most Powerful 2017: Philanthropy & Community Voices" list in the Orlando Magazine July 2017issue. 

[[Private Property (1960 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 drama movies, 1960s crime drama movies, American crime drama movies, American independent movies

Private Property, sometimes credited as Private Property!, is a 1960 American crime drama movie directed by Leslie Stevens and starring Corey Allen, Warren Oates, Jerome Cowan, Kate Manx. It was distributed by Citation Films.

[[Papaléo Paes]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian politicians

João Bosco Papaléo Paes (August 27, 1952 – June 25, 2020), better known simply as Papaléo Paes, was a Brazilian politician. Paes was born in Belém, Pará. 

Paes was Mayor of Macapá from 1993 to 1996. He was a Senator from 2003 to 2011. He was also Vice-Governor of Amapá from 2015 to 2018. He was a member of the Brazilian Social Democracy Party.

Paes died on June 25, 2020 from COVID-19 in Macapá, aged 67.

[[Jenna Marbles]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, American Internet celebrities, American movie actors, American LGBT rights activists, Actors from New York, Comedians from New York, People from Rochester, New York, American bloggers

Jenna Nicole Mourey (born September 15, 1986), better known by her pseudonym Jenna Marbles, is an American YouTube personality, vlogger, comedian, and actress. As of September 2019, her channel had about 3.3 billion video views and 20 million subscribers.

She is the 86th most subscribed channel on YouTube and the eighth-most-popular channel operated by a woman. Mourey is the first social media star to have a wax figure shown at Madame Tussauds Museum in New York City.

On June 25, 2020, Mourey uploaded a YouTube video, in which she apologized for past offensive comments and blackface. She said that she would be quitting from her YouTube channel.

Mourey was born in Rochester, New York. She studied at Suffolk University and Boston University.

[[Tyler Oakley]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, LGBT actors, LGBT writers, Gay men, American YouTubers, American movie actors, American LGBT rights activists, American political commentators, American autobiographers, Writers from Michigan, Actors from Michigan, People from Jackson, Michigan, American bloggers, Twitch (service) streamers

Matthew Tyler Oakley (born March 22, 1989) is an American YouTuber, actor, activist and author. His activism has been dedicated to LGBTQ+ youth, LGBT rights, as well as social issues including health care, education, and the prevention of suicide among LGBT youth. He was born in Jackson, Michigan.

Oakley began making videos in 2007. Oakley, who is openly gay, is a former member of the successful collaboration channel "5AwesomeGays," where he produced the Friday video for over three years.

[[James Charles]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, Living people, American YouTubers, LGBT businesspeople, Gay men, LGBT artists, Businesspeople from New York, LGBT people from New York, American TikTokers, Twitch (service) streamers

James Charles Dickinson (born May 23, 1999) is an American Internet personality, beauty YouTuber and make-up artist. In 2016, he became the first male ambassador for CoverGirl.

Charles is most known for his YouTube channel focusing on makeup, which he launched on December 1, 2015. It currently has 19.5 million subscribers, making him the #1 most subscribed beauty guru. His Tik Tok buddies are Addison Rae, Charli D’Amelio, Chase Hudson, and Avani Gregg.

On May 6, 2019, his channel had 16.6 million subscribers, and on May 11, 2019, he became the first ever YouTube personality to lose over 1 million subscribers in 24 hours.

On October 11, 2016, at the age of seventeen, Charles became the first male spokesperson for cosmetics brand CoverGirl.

[[Michael Stevens]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, American educators, American editors, Comedians from Missouri, Internet celebrities, Writers from Kansas City, Missouri

Michael David Stevens (born January 23, 1986) is an American educator, public speaker, comedian, entertainer, editor, and internet celebrity. He is best known for creating and hosting the popular education YouTube channel Vsauce. His videos are about the explanations of science, philosophy, culture, and illusion.

As the host of Vsauce, Stevens has become one of the most successful YouTubers. He was born in Kansas City, Missouri.

In 2017, he created and starred in the YouTube Premium series Mind Field, and presented the nationwide educational stage tour Brain Candy Live! alongside Adam Savage.

[[Monkey Business (1952 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Howard Hawks, 20th Century Fox movies

Monkey Business is a 1952 American comedy movie directed by Howard Hawks and starring Cary Grant, Ginger Rogers, Marilyn Monroe, Hugh Marlowe, Esther Dale, Charles Coburn. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Hannah Hart]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, Internet celebrities, American movie actors, LGBT comedians, LGBT actors, LGBT writers, LGBT producers, Lesbians, Writers from California, Actors from California, Movie producers from California, LGBT people from California, People from Palo Alto, California

Hannah Maud Hart (born November 2, 1986) is an American internet personality, comedian, author, and actress. She is known for starring in My Drunk Kitchen, a weekly series on YouTube in which she cooks something while drunk. 

She also runs a second channel where she talks about life in general and gives her opinions on many topics. She co-produced and starred in the independent comedy movie Camp Takota, released in 2014. 

She wrote a parody cookbook which was a New York Times bestseller for five weeks in August–September 2014. She is a 2017 recipient of the Alex Awards.

Hart was born in Palo Alto, California. She studied at the University of California, Berkeley. Hart is a lesbian.

[[His Girl Friday]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 movies, 1940s comedy movies, 1940s drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Howard Hawks

His Girl Friday is a 1940 American screwball comedy drama romance movie directed by Howard Hawks and based on the 1928 play The Front Page by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur. It stars Cary Grant, Rosalind Russell and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Kankan Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

Kankan is a region in the east of Guinea. It is bordered by the countries of Mali and Côte d'Ivoire and the Guinean regions of Nzérékoré and Faranah. The regional capital is the city of Kankan. As of the 2014 census, 1,986,329 people lived there. It has an area of 72.145.

[[Labé Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

Labé is a region in north-central Guinea. It is bordered by the countries of Senegal and Mali and the Guinean regions of Faranah, Kindia, Mamou, and Boké. The regional capital is the city of Labé. As of the 2014 census, 995,717 people lived there. It has an area of 22.869.

[[Mamou Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

Mamou is a region in the center of Guinea. It is bordered by the country of Sierra Leone and the Guinean regions of Faranah, Labé, and Kindia. The regional capital is the city of Mamou. As of the 2014 census, 732,117 people lived there. It has an area of 17.074.

[[Nzérékoré Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Guinea

Nzérékoré is a region in the south of Guinea. It is bordered by the countries of Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Ivory Coast, and the Guinean regions of Kankan and Faranah. The regional capital is the city of Nzérékoré. As of the 2014 census, 1,663,582 people lived there. It has an area of 37.658.

CATEGORIES: 1920 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Lanier County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 10,078 people lived there. The county seat is Lakeland.

CATEGORIES: 1832 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Lumpkin County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 29,966 people lived there. The county seat is Dahlonega.

Ellijay is a city in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is the county seat of Gilmer County.

[[Montval-sur-Loir]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Sarthe

Montval-sur-Loir is a commune. It is found in the Pays de la Loire region in the Sarthe department in the west of France. The municipality was created on 1 October 2016 and consists of the former communes of Château-du-Loir (the seat), Montabon and Vouvray-sur-Loir.

[[Louis Aliot]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, French lawyers, People from Toulouse

Louis Aliot (aljo; born 4 September 1969) is a French politician, a lawyer by profession, and the vice president of the National Rally (previously named National Front) since 16 January 2011. Louis Aliot is the mayor of Perpignan since July 3, 2020.

[[Tuffé-Val-de-la-Chéronne]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Sarthe

Tuffé-Val-de-la-Chéronne is a commune. It is found in the Pays de la Loire region in the Sarthe department in the west of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 and consists of the former communes of Tuffé (the seat) and Saint-Hilaire-le-Lierru.

[[Val-d'Étangson]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 establishments in France, Communes in Sarthe

Val-d'Étangson is a commune. It is found in the Pays de la Loire region in the Sarthe department in the west of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Évaillé (the seat) and Sainte-Osmane.

[[Villeneuve-en-Perseigne]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 establishments in France, Communes in Sarthe

Villeneuve-en-Perseigne is a commune. It is found in the Pays de la Loire region in the Sarthe department in the west of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2015 and consists of the former communes of La Fresnaye-sur-Chédouet (the seat), Chassé, Lignières-la-Carelle, Montigny, Roullée and Saint-Rigomer-des-Bois.

[[Pottage]]

A pottage is a warm meal made with cereal that has been boiled or stewed in usually water or milk.

[[The Marriage of Mr. Mississippi]]

The Marriage of Mr. Mississippi (Die Ehe des Herrn Mississippi) is a 1961 Swiss West German comedy movie directed by Kurt Hoffmann and based on the 1952 play of the same title by Friedrich Dürrenmatt. It stars O.E. Hasse, Johanna von Koczian, Martin Held and was distributed by UFA.

[[Sfax Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 establishments in Tunisia, Governorates of Tunisia

Sfax Governorate (ولاية صفاقس ar) is one of the twenty-four governorates of Tunisia. It is in the eastern coast of the country, and includes the Kerkennah Islands. It covers an area of 7,545 km². As of the 2014 census, 955,421 people lived there. The capital is Sfax.

[[Sidi Bouzid Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Tunisia, 1973 establishments in Africa, Governorates of Tunisia

Sidi Bouzid Governorate (ولاية سيدي بوزيد aeb) is one of the twenty-four governorates of Tunisia. It is in the central part of the country. It covers an area of 7405 km². As of the 2014 census, 429,912 people lived there. The capital is Sidi Bouzid.

[[Fourteen Hours]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 drama movies, 1950s crime movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on short stories, Movies directed by Henry Hathaway

Fourteen Hours is a 1951 American crime drama movie directed by Henry Hathaway and based on the 1949 short story The Man on the Ledge by Joel Sayre. It stars Paul Douglas, Richard Basehart, Barbara Bel Geddes, Debra Paget, Agnes Moorehead, Jeffrey Hunter, Grace Kelly and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1952.

I'll Get You for This is a 1951 British crime thriller movie directed by Joseph M. Newman and based on the 1946 novel of the same name by James Hadley Chase. It stars George Raft, Coleen Gray, Enzo Staiola, Charles Goldner, Walter Rilla, Peter Illing, Elwyn Brook-Jones and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

Miori Shimosaka (下坂美織) is a Japanese professional Go player at Nihon Ki-in. She was born at Hokkaido Prefecture.

[[Sol Heras]]

[[Melk]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Lower Austria

Melk is a city in the Austrian state of Lower Austria. It is the capital of the district of the same name. It is best known as the site of a massive baroque Benedictine monastery named Melk Abbey. The city has a long history, it was first mentioned in the 9th century. Part of the city is a UNESCO world heritage site.

[[Leoben]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Styria

Leoben is a city in the Austrian state of Styria. It is on the Mur river and has about 25,000 people. The University of Leoben is in the city.

[[Retz]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Lower Austria

Retz is a town of the district of Hollabrunn in the Austrian state of Lower Austria.

[[Cannabinoid]]

CATEGORIES: Cannabis

A cannabinoid is a chemical found in the cannabis (marijuana) plant. There are 113 cannabinoids that scientists know of, but there are likely more. Two of the best known cannabinoids are tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD). THC is a psychoactive drug, meaning it can make you feel and think differently. Not all cannabinoids are psychoactive and each one works differently. All cannabinoids share a similar chemical structure and are researched for treating diseases.

[[Watchareeya Nuanjam]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, Volleyball players, Thai sportspeople

Watchareeya Nuanjam (born 22 July 1996) is a Thai volleyball player.

She played at the 2017 Asian Women's Club Volleyball Championship, 2017 Asian Women's U23 Volleyball Championship, 2017 FIVB Volleyball Women's U23 World Championship, 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship, and 2019 FIVB Volleyball Women's Nations League. She played for Supreme VC and Supreme Chonburi.

[[Serbia and Montenegro national football team]]

CATEGORIES: National football teams

The Serbia and Montenegro national football team (Fudbalska reprezentacija Srbije i Crne Gore) was a national football team that represented the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro. It was controlled by the Football Association of Serbia and Montenegro. 

For 11 years, it was known as the FR Yugoslavia national football team (Fudbalska reprezentacija SR Jugoslavije) when the state was called the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, until February 2003, when the name of the country was changed to Serbia and Montenegro. 

In 2006, Montenegro declared its independence from Serbia, with the result that the country's football team was renamed as the Serbia national football team on 28 June 2006 with the Montenegro national football team created to represent the renewed state of Montenegro.

[[Ilija Petković]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from ulcers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Serbia, Serbian football managers, Serbian footballers, Yugoslavian sportspeople

Ilija Petković (Илија Петковић, ǐlija pětkoʋitɕ; 22 September 1945 – 27 June 2020) was a Serbian footballer and manager. From the early 1990s until his death, Petković was a football manager. He was manager of the Serbia and Montenegro national team from 2003 to 2006. He was born in Knin, then-Yugoslavia.

Petković died on 27 June 2020 in Belgrade from problems caused by an ulcer and COVID-19, aged 74.

[[Sara Lozo]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, Living people, Serbian volleyball players

Sara Lozo (born 29 April 1997) is a Serbian volleyball player.

She played at the 2014 Women's Junior European Volleyball Championship, 2015 FIVB Volleyball Women's U20 World Championship, 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix, 2017 Women's European Volleyball Championship, 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's Nations League, 2019 FIVB Volleyball Women's Nations League, and 2019 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Cup.

She played for Vizura Ruma and VC Zhetysu.

[[Milutin Knežević]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian people, Bishops, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Serbia

Milutin Knežević (Милутин Кнежевић; 10 January 1949 – 30 March 2020) was a Serbian Orthodox prelate, Bishop of the Eparchy of Australia and New Zealand between 2003 and 2006, and the Eparchy of Valjevo from 2006 to 2020. 

He died on 30 March 2020, from problems due to COVID-19. He became first Eastern Orthodox bishop who died of COVID-19.

[[Silas Silvius Njiru]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Kenyan people, Roman Catholic bishops, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy

Silas Silvius Njiru (10 October 1928 – 28 April 2020) was a Kenyan Roman Catholic bishop. He was born in Kevote, Kenya.

Njiru was ordained to the priesthood in 1955. He served as titular bishop of Maturba and auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Meru, Kenya, in 1975 and 1976. Njiru then served as bishop of the Meru Diocese from 1976 to 2004. 

Njiru died on 28 April 2020 from COVID-19 in Rivoli, Piedmont, Italy at the age of 91.

[[Ito Curata]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Filipino businesspeople, Fashion designers, LGBT fashion designers, Gay men, 2020 deaths, People from Manila, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines, Deaths from pneumonia

Ito Curata (2 November 1959 – 26 March 2020) was a Filipino fashion designer. He worked creating bridal gowns and Filipiniana clothing. His well known clients were Hollywood actress Sharon Stone, former Philippine president Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, and Filipino actress Bea Alonzo. He was born in Manila.

He and his partner Miller were hospitalized in mid march due to COVID-19 symptoms in Manila. Curata died on March 26, 2020 due to pneumonia caused by the infection, aged 60.

[[Jovana Jovičić]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Serbian volleyball players

Jovana Jovičić (born 20 July 1994) is a Serbian volleyball player.

She played at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's Nations League. 

She played for Železničar Lajkovac.

[[Antonio Cuenco]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines, Filipino politicians

Antonio "Tony" Veloso Cuenco (March 26, 1936 – June 27, 2020) was a Filipino politician. He was a council member for the 2nd District of the Cebu City Council. He also was the Secretary-General of the ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly (AIPA) from 2010 to 2013. He was representative of the 2nd District of Cebu City in the House of Representatives from 1965 to 1969, 1987 to 1998 and 2001 to 2010. 

Cuenco died on June 27, 2020 in Cebu City from COVID-19, aged 84.

[[Vehbi Akdağ]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Turkish sportspeople, Olympic silver medalists, Wrestlers

Vehbi Akdağ (1 January 1949 – 23 June 2020) was a Turkish wrestler. He was an Olympic silver medalist in Freestyle wrestling. Akdağ competed at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich where he won a silver medal in featherweight class in Freestyle wrestling He was born in Tokat, Turkey.

Akdağ died on 23 June 2020 in Tokat, aged 71.

[[Abdoulatifou Aly]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Malagasy people, French politicians

Abdoulatifou Aly (12 April 1960 – 26 June 2020) was a Malagasy-born French politician. He was a member of the French National Assembly from 2007 until he lost his re-election in 2012. He was a member of the Movement for the Development of Mayotte. Aly was born in Antsiranana, Madagascar. 

Aly died at a hospital on 26 June 2020 in Mamoudzou, Mayotte at the age of 60.

[[Siliana Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 establishments in Tunisia, Governorates of Tunisia

Siliana Governorate (ولاية سليانة aeb ˌsɪlˈjæːnæ) is one of the twenty-four governorates of Tunisia. It is in the northern part of the country. It covers an area of 4,631 km². As of the 2014 census, 223,087 people lived there. The capital is Siliana.

[[Taryn Power]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from leukemia, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California

[[Romina Power]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Singers from Los Angeles, California

Romina Francesca Power (born October 2, 1951) is an American actress and singer. 

She appeared in several mainly Italian-language movies from the age of 14, including the 1969 version of the Marquis de Sade's novel Justine, directed by Jesus Franco.

In 2005 Power was a judge in the Italian TV show Ballando con le Stelle (Dancing with the Stars).

[[Lords Temporal]]

CATEGORIES: United Kingdom

The Lords Temporal are secular members of the House of Lords, the upper house of the British Parliament. The term is used to create a difference between these members — who are either life peers or hereditary peers. The House of Lords ended for good, but ninety-two peers during the 1999 reform of the House of Lords.

[[Hereditary peer]]

CATEGORIES: United Kingdom

The hereditary peers form part of the peerage in the United Kingdom. As of 2020 there are 814 hereditary peers: 31 dukes (including 7 royal dukes), 34 marquesses, 193 earls, 112 viscounts, and 444 barons.

From 1963 to 1999, all non-Irish peers were entitled to sit in the House of Lords, but since the House of Lords Act 1999 was passed, only 92 are permitted to do so, unless they are also life peers. 

Peers are called to the House of Lords with a writ of summons.

[[Maja Aleksić]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, Living people, Serbian volleyball players

Maja Aleksić (born 6 June 1997) is a Serbian volleyball player.

She played at the 2015 FIVB Volleyball Women's U20 World Championship, 2016 Montreux Volley Masters, 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's Nations League, 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 2019 FIVB Volleyball Women's Nations League, and 2019 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Cup.

She played for CS Volei Alba BLAJ. 

[[Diana Maddock, Baroness Maddock]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, UK MPs 1992–1997, People from Northumberland

Diana Margaret Maddock, Baroness Maddock, Lady Beith (19 May 1945 – 26 June 2020) was a British Liberal Democrat politician. She was born in Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland. Between 1993 to 1997, she was a Member of Parliament for Christchurch. In 1997, Maddock became a Lord Temporal. From 1999 to 2000, she was President of the Liberal Democrats.

Maddock died on 26 June 2020 at her home in Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland at the age of 75.

[[Ivana Eloisa Müller]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Argentine volleyball players, Living people

Ivana Eloisa Müller (born 7 March 1974) is an Argentine volleyball player.

She played at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Phone Limited Modena and Figurella Firenze.

[[István Kausz]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Hungarian sportspeople, Olympic gold medalists

István Kausz (18 August 1932 – 3 June 2020) was a Hungarian fencer. He won a gold medal in the team épée event at the 1964 Summer Olympics. He was born in Budapest. 

Kaudz died in Budapest on 3 June 2020, aged 87.

[[2017 Formula One World Championship]]

CATEGORIES: Formula One seasons, 2017 in sports

The 2017 Formula One World Championship is the 68th season of the Formula One World Championship. The motor racing championship is the highest class of competition for open-wheel racing cars.

The 2017 season started with the Australian Grand Prix on March 26 2017, and ended with Abu Dhabi Grand Prix on November 26 2017.

[[Veli Lehtelä]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Finnish Olympic bronze medalists, Rowers

Veli Veikko Valtteri Lehtelä (6 September 1935 – 3 June 2020) was a Finnish rower. He competed in various two-man and four man events at the 1956, 1960 and 1964 Olympics and won two bronze medals, in 1956 and 1960. He was born in Sääksmäki, Finland.

Lehtelä died on 3 June 2020 in Helsinki, aged 84.

[[Mirna Ansaldi]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Argentine volleyball players, Living people

Mirna Eugenia Ansaldi (born 10 July 1977) is an Argentine volleyball player.

She played at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 2005 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, 2006 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, and 2008 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup.

On club level she played with Gimnasia y Esgrima de Rosario.

[[1970s energy crisis]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s in the United States, Economic history

The 1970s energy crisis happened when the Western world, mainly in the United States, Canada, Western Europe, Australia, and New Zealand, faced large petroleum shortages as well as inflated prices. The two worst crises of this period were the 1973 oil crisis and the 1979 energy crisis, when the Yom Kippur War and the Iranian Revolution caused an interruptions in Middle Eastern oil exports.

[[Moral Equivalent of War speech]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 in the United States, Jimmy Carter

United States President Jimmy Carter's Moral Equivalent of War speech was a speech in which Carter addressed the United States on April 18, 1977. It is remembered as the speech where he compared the energy crisis with the "moral equivalent of war". He said the goal was to lower dependence on oil imports and "cut in half the portion of United States oil which is imported, from a potential level of 16 million barrels to six million barrels a day."

The phrase has become so well known, it is referenced in literature. 

[[Natalia Brussa]]

CATEGORIES: Argentine volleyball players, Living people, 1985 births

Natalia Guadalupe Brussa (born 13 February 1985) is an Argentine volleyball player.

She played at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Scavolini Pesaro, Universal Modena, and Tauron MKS Dabrowa Gornicza.

[[Rationing]]

CATEGORIES: Military tactics

Rationing is when a person gives away a low amount of an already lowering amount of resources, goods, services, or an artificial restriction of demand. 

Rationing controls the size of the ration, which is one's allowed portion of the resources being distributed on a particular day or at a particular time.

[[Love Canal]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in New York

Love Canal is a neighborhood in Niagara Falls, New York. It is known as the location of a 70 landfill that became the site of a massive environmental disaster in the 1970s. After years of dumping toxic chemicals harmed the health of hundreds of residents; the area was cleaned up over the course of 21 years in a Superfund operation.

It is seen as a "national symbol of a failure to exercise a sense of concern for future generations". 

[[Superfund]]

CATEGORIES: United States federal legislation

The United States federal Superfund law is officially known as the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA). The federal Superfund program is controlled by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). It is designed to investigate and clean up sites contaminated with toxic waste. 

Sites managed under this program are known as "Superfund" sites. There are 40,000 federal Superfund sites across the country, and about 1,600 of those sites have been listed on the National Priorities List (NPL). 

[[Mariana Conde]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Argentine volleyball players, Living people

Mariana  Isabel Conde (born 23 July 1973) is an Argentine volleyball player.

She played at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Volley 2000 Spezzano and Volley Modena.

[[1973–1975 recession]]

CATEGORIES: 1973, 1974 in the United States, 1975 in North America

The 1973–1975 recession or 1970s recession was a period of economic stagnation in much of the Western world during the 1970s. It was different from many previous recessions by being a stagflation, where high unemployment and high inflation existed at the same time. 

Among the causes were the 1973 oil crisis and the fall of the Bretton Woods system after the Nixon Shock.

The recession in the United States lasted from November 1973 (the Richard Nixon presidency) to March 1975 (the Gerald Ford presidency), and its effects on the US were felt through the Jimmy Carter presidency until the mid-term of Ronald Reagan's first term as president.

[[Nixon shock]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 in the United States, Economic history, Richard Nixon

The Nixon shock was a series of economic measures done by United States President Richard Nixon in 1971, in response to increasing inflation. He froze wage and price. He also directed the cancellation of the direct international convertibility of the United States dollar to gold.

[[Consumer confidence]]

CATEGORIES: Economic indicators

Consumer confidence is an economic word that measures the degree of optimism that consumers feel about the overall state of the economy and their personal financial situation. If the consumer has confidence in the economy, it is more likely they will spend money rather than save money.

[[Airline Deregulation Act]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 in the United States, United States federal legislation

The Airline Deregulation Act is a 1978 United States federal law that deregulated the airline business in the United States. It removed all of the federal government control over such areas as fares, routes, and market entry of new airlines. 

It introduced a free market in the commercial airline business and led to a great increase in the number of flights, a decrease in fares, an increase in the number of passengers and miles flown, and a consolidation of carriers.

[[Romina Lamas]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Argentine volleyball players, Living people

Romina Lamas (born Romina Gueren, 29 August 1978 in Buenos Aires) is an Argentine volleyball player. She played at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Igtisadchi Baku, Çanakkale Belediyespor, Hainaut Volley, Aguere La Laguna, and CV Tenerife. She won the MVP at the 2010/11 Spanish Cup, and best setter at 2016/17 Spanish Superliga 2.

[[Airline deregulation]]

CATEGORIES: United States federal legislation, Economic policy

Airline deregulation is the process of removing government-controlled entry and price restrictions on airlines affecting, in particular, the carriers allowed to fly specific routes. 

In the United States, the term usually connects to the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978. A new form of regulation has been created to some extent to deal with problems such as the given away the limited number of slots available at airports.

[[Commercial aviation]]

CATEGORIES: Aviation

Commercial aviation is the part of civil aviation (both general aviation and scheduled airline services) that involves working  aircraft for hire to transport passengers or multiple loads of  cargo.

The Air Commerce Act of 1926 began to allow commercial aviation by creating standards, facilitation, and promotion.

[[Civil Aeronautics Board]]

CATEGORIES: Agencies

The Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) was an agency of the federal government of the United States, formed in 1938 and ended in 1985. It regulated aviation services including scheduled passenger airline service and provided air accident investigation. The agency headquarters were in Washington, D.C.

[[Deregulation]]

CATEGORIES: Economic policy

Deregulation is the process of removing or lowering state regulations, usually for economic purposes.  It is the reversing of governmental regulation of the economy.  It became widely used in industrial economies in the 1970s and 1980s, as a result of new forms in economic thinking.

Economic regulations were promoted during the Gilded Age, in which progressive reforms were seen as important to make sure companies do not abuse labor laws.

[[Regulation]]

CATEGORIES: Economic policy

Regulation is the management of complex systems. It is based on a set of rules and trends. In systems theory, these types of rules exist in many parts of biology and society, but the term has slightly different meanings. For example:

The opposite of regulation is deregulation.

[[Homebrewing]]

CATEGORIES: Beer-related culture

Homebrewing is the making beer, mead, and ciders in small amounts for personal use, not for sale. In the United States, a permit is required to distill spirits such as moonshine.

[[Jimmy Carter Regional Airport]]

CATEGORIES: Jimmy Carter, Airports in the United States, Buildings and structures in Georgia (U.S. state), 1910s establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), 1918 establishments in the United States

Jimmy Carter Regional Airport  previously Souther Field is a public airport located four miles (6 km) northeast of the central business district of Americus, in Sumter County, Georgia, United States. It owned by the Sumter County and Airport Authority.

[[USS Jimmy Carter]]

CATEGORIES: Jimmy Carter, United States Navy

USS ''Jimmy Carter'' (SSN-23) is the third and final Seawolf, nuclear-powered, fast-attack submarine in the United States Navy. She is named for Jimmy Carter, the 39th President of the United States. Jimmy Carter is one of the few ships of the United States Navy and the third submarine to be named for a living person, and the only submarine to be named for a living president.

[[Wake Up! (Pope Francis album)]]

CATEGORIES: Progressive rock albums

Wake Up! Music Album with His Words and Prayers is a progressive rock album by Pope Francis released on 27 November 2015 on Believe Digital. The album is actually just speeches by Pope Francis recorded in many locations worldwide between 2013 and 2015. It also has music tracks of prayers and hymns by many Italian artists and producers.

[[Statenville, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

Statenville is a census-designated place (CDP) in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is the county seat of Echols County.

[[Machynlleth]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Powys, Market towns in Wales

Machynlleth, sometimes known locally as just Mach, is a historic market town, community and electoral ward in the county of Powys in Wales. It is inside the historic boundaries of Montgomeryshire.

Machynlleth was the seat of Owain Glyndŵr's Welsh Parliament in 1404, and because of this, says it is the "ancient capital of Wales". However, it has never held any official recognition as a capital. It applied for city status in 2000 and 2002, but was unsuccessful. 

Welsh is spoken by many as well as English. The 2011 Census found that 67% of the town's people had some knowledge of the Welsh language, with 39% able to read, write and speak the language.

[[House of Cards (1968 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 movies, 1960s crime movies, 1960s mystery movies, American mystery movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by John Guillermin, Movies set in Rome

House of Cards is a 1968 American crime mystery movie directed by John Guillermin and starring George Peppard, Inger Stevens, Orson Welles, Maxine Audley, Keith Michell, Peter Bayliss, Patience Collier. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and was based on the novel of the same name by Stanley Ellin.

Boone County is a county in the U.S. state of West Virginia. As of the 2010 census, 24,629 people lived there. Its county seat is Madison.

Marion County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 8,742 people lived there. The county seat is Buena Vista.

[[A Soldier's Story]]

A Soldier's Story is a 1984 American drama movie directed by Norman Jewison and based on the 1981 play of the same name by Charles Fuller. It stars Howard Rollins, Adolph Caesar, David Alan Grier, Art Evans, Denzel Washington, Patti LaBelle, Wings Hauser, Dennis Lipscomb and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was nominated for 3 Academy Awards in 1985.

[[Barmouth]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Gwynedd

Barmouth (Welsh: Abermaw (formal); Y Bermo (informal)) is a seaside town and community in the county of Gwynedd, Wales. It lies on the estuary of the River Mawddach and Cardigan Bay. It is located in the historic county of Merionethshire.

In the 2011 census, the town had a population of 2,522 people.

The town grew around the shipbuilding industry, and more recently grew as a seaside resort. It is a popular holiday destination for people around the West Midlands area of England, with thousands of holiday makers and tourists flocking to the town from this region every year.

The town has a railway station located on the Cambrian Coast Line between Pwllheli and Shrewsbury.

[[Knighton, Powys]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Powys

Knighton (Welsh: Tref-y-clawdd) is a small market town and community in the county of Powys, Wales that straddles the England–Wales border. It is in the historic county of Radnorshire.

Part of the town, including Knighton railway station, is in Shropshire, England. 

At the 2011 census, the town had a population of 3,172 people; 3,007 of which lived in Powys and 140 in Shropshire.

On the last Saturday in August, the town holds an annual Carnival and Show, which attracts visitors from all around the world. Its two parades, one at midday and another around 8 pm, consist of various themed carnival floats with people in fancy dress. The show takes place at the town's showground at Bryn-y-Castell, which is also home to Knighton Town Football Club, Knighton Cricket Club and Knighton Hockey Club.

[[Pwllheli]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Gwynedd

Pwllheli is a seaside resort and community in the county of Gwynedd in Wales. It is also the main market town of the Llŷn Peninsula.

In 2011, the community had a population of 4,076 people, of which 81%, are speakers of the Welsh language.

The town's name means salt water basin.

The political party Plaid Cymru (The Party of Wales) was founded in Pwllheli.

The town is the northern terminus of the Cambrian Coast Line railway line from Shrewsbury.

[[Cambrian Line]]

CATEGORIES: Rail transport in Wales, Railway lines of England

The Cambrian Line (Welsh: Rheilffordd y Cambrian), sometimes called the Cambrian Coast Line, is a railway line that runs from Shrewsbury, England to Aberystwyth and Pwllheli, Wales.

It is a very scenic route. It runs through the Cambrian Mountains in central Wales and along the coast of Cardigan Bay.

[[A11 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A11, also called l'Océane (the Ocean) in French, is an autoroute (motorway) in France. It goes from the A10 near Ponthevrard to Nantes. With the A10, it links Nantes with Paris. The autoroute is about 343 long. It is also part of the European routes E50, E501, and E60.

[[Byzantine Armenia]]

CATEGORIES: Armenia

Byzantine Armenia, sometimes known as Western Armenia, is the name given to parts of the Kingdom of Armenia that became part of the Byzantine Empire (eastern Roman Empire). The size of the area changed multiple times through the course of history.

The Byzantine and Sassanid Empires divided Armenia in 387 and 428 AD. Western Armenia was part of Byzantine rule, whilst Eastern Armenia (Persianized Armenia) was part of the Sassanids. Even after the Bagratid Armenian Kingdom was created, parts of historic Armenia and Armenian-inhabited areas were still under Byzantine rule.

[[Battle of Kaiapit]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s in Oceania, 1943, Pacific battles of World War II, History of Papua New Guinea, Battles involving Australia, Battles involving Japan, Battles involving the United States, September events

The Battle of Kaiapit was fought in 1943 between Australian and Japanese forces in New Guinea during the Finisterre Range campaign of World War II. Following landings at Nadzab and at Lae, the Allies attempted to exploit their success with an advance into the upper Markham Valley, starting with Kaiapit. The Australian 2/6th Independent Company flew into the valley from Port Moresby in 13 USAAF C-47 Dakotas, making a difficult landing on a rough airstrip. Unaware that a much larger Japanese force was also headed for Kaiapit and Nadzab, the company attacked the village on 19 September to secure the area so that it could be developed into an airfield. They then held it against a strong counterattack. During two days of fighting the larger force, the Australians suffered relatively few losses. Their victory at Kaiapit enabled the Australian 7th Division to be flown into the upper Markham Valley, stopping the Japanese from threatening Lae or Nadzab, where a major airbase was being developed. The victory also led to the capture of the Ramu Valley, which provided new forward fighter airstrips for the air war.

[[Bridled frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The bridled frog, bridle frog or tawny rocket frog (Litoria nigrofrenata) is a frog from Australia and Papua New Guinea. It lives in the Cape York Peninsula, islands in the Torres Strait, and northern Queensland and the Northern Territory.

This frog is about 4.5 cm long.  It is pale tan to dark red-brown in colour.  This frog is known for its very clear black stripes, which can be long or short.

This frog lives in forests and swamps near dams and small streams.

It lays eggs 450 at a time in pools and streams.

[[Winners and Sinners]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 action movies, 1983 comedy movies, Hong Kong movies, Movies directed by Sammo Hung

Winners and Sinners (奇謀妙計五福星, also known as 5 Lucky Stars) is a 1983 Hong Kong action comedy movie directed by Sammo Hung (who also stars) and starring Jackie Chan, John Shum, Richard Ng, Charlie Chin, Stanley Fung, Cherie Chung, Yuen Biao. It was distributed by Golden Harvest Pictures.

[[Paramathma]]

CATEGORIES: Hinduism

Paramathma also known as Parabrahman or highest atman is the ultimate destination where all atmans unite after moksha. Paramathma is the eternal truth, bliss, and knowledge. In Hinduism, Lord Shiva (The destroyer) and Lord Maha Vishnu (The preserver and the sustainer of the universe) are the two forms of Paramathma. 

Paramathma is the first and foremost atman. He believed to have the highest level of knowledge and energy creates, preserves, sustains, and destroys all life. The Power and Energy of Paramathma is thought to be ineffable.

Paramathma is believed to have supermystical powers because of his penance. The Paramathma is the one who is in everything and an ananta(eternal or Infinite). The Atman is immortal as the Paramathma since all atmans are a part of Paramathma. He is a pure personification of everything beyond conceptualization and manifestation. 

[[Forest of the Gods]]

It stars Valentinas Masalskis, Steven Berkoff, Liubomiras Laucevičius, Rolandas Boravskis, Šarūnas Puidokas, Robertas Urbonas, Saulius Mykolaitis and Monika Bičiūnaitė.

[[Enemies, A Love Story (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s romantic drama movies, 1989 romance movies, 1989 drama movies, American romantic drama movies, English-language movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Paul Mazursky

Enemies, A Love Story is a 1989 American romantic drama movie directed by Paul Mazursky and based on the 1966 novel Enemies, A Love Story (Sonim, di Geshichte fun a Liebe) by Isaac Bashevis Singer. It stars Anjelica Huston, Ron Silver, Lena Olin, Margaret Sophie Stein, Alan King and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for three Academy Awards in 1990.

[[Manuela Benelli]]

She coached for Roma Pallavolo, Vicenza Volley, and Volley 2002 Forlì.

She played for Zarechie-Odintsovo, Severyanka Cherepovets, WVC Dynamo Moscow, and Fakel Novy Urengoy.

[[Wallum sedge frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The wallum sedge frog or olongburra frog (Litoria olongburensis) is a frog from eastern Australia.  It lives in Queensland and New South Wales.

The adult male frogs is 2.5 cm long and the female is 2.7 to 3.1 cm long.  It is gray, brown or bright green, with blue or orange colour on its legs.  It has brown and white stripes and a white belly.  It has only a little webbing on the front feet and more on the hind feet.  It has large discs on its toes for climbing.  It has vomerine teeth in its upper jaw.

This frog lives near the ocean and on islands with sandy soil.  It lives in creeks and marshes that have acidic water (pH 2.8-5.5), such as wallums.  If the water becomes less acidic, then other frogs move in and eat all the food. Adult frogs climb on sedge plants during the day.

This frog lays eggs in acidic water (pH < 6) in temporary or semi-permanent swamps.  They lay eggs 200-1000 at a time near sedge plants.

This frog is also in danger because humans like to build things in the places where they live.  Humans like beaches and seashores, so they sometimes walk over the grasses and shore plants where the frog likes to hide during the day.  Scientists also think the fungal disease chytridiomycosis might be killing these frogs.

Scientists think this frog is also in danger because of invasive species.  Plants from other places might change the places where these frogs like to live.  Frogs from other places eat all their food.  Fish from other places, such as mosquito fish, eat the tadpoles and eggs.  Feral pigs can also run through the wallums and damage them. 

[[Naive set theory]]

CATEGORIES: Set theory

When people started to talk about sets, mostly in the 19th century, they did this using natural language. It uses many of the concepts already known from discrete mathematics; for example Venn diagrams to show which elements are contained in a set, or Boolean algebra. It is powerful enough for many areas of contemporary mathematics and engineering. The term naive set theory is used for this kinds of set theory. It is usually contrasted with axiomatic set theory.

Naive set theory leads to a number of problems:

There is a problem though: All the problems above can only be shown to be problems when axioms can be used to describe sets and their properties. 

Richard Dedekind (1831-1916) discovered this and started a new set theory, in 1888. In his set theory, there are axioms about sets. His set theory is not good enough though:

Ernst Zermelo published a set theory in 1908. It uses axioms to define sets, and very much limits the ways in which sets can be made. Together with   Abraham Fraenkel he is one of the creators of Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory, the set theory that was used for the much of the 20th century. Because of Gödel's incompleteness theorems this can only be proved for finite sets, though.

When teaching about sets in schools, naive set theory and the definition of Georg Cantor are sometimes used.

[[Eastern mosquitofish]]

CATEGORIES: Fish

The eastern mosquitofish, eastern gambusia,  or mosquito fish (Gambusia holbrooki) is a fish that belongs to the Poeciliidae family.  It is from the eastern United States but human beings brought it to many other parts of the world, such as Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and Australia, where it has caused problems as an invasive specie.

The adult male eastern mosquitofish grows to 3.5 cm and the female to 6.0 cm.  It is green or brown on top and blue, white or silver on the bottom.  It has large eyes and one dorsal fin and a round tail fin.

This fish likes to live in fresh water but can live in water that has some salt.  It can survive cold and warm temperatures.  It eats insects and their larvae.

People brought the eastern mosquitofish to Hawaii in the 1910s and to Australia in the 1920s and set it free there.  They thought it would eat mosquito larvae so there would be fewer mosquitoes.  But the eastern mosquitofish did not eat more mosquitoes than the fish that were already in Australia did.  The eastern mosquitofish outcompetes other fish and bites their tails or even eats them.  It can kill larger fish by damaging their fins.  In the western United States, the eastern mosquitofish killed or outcompeted many other fish that were better at controlling mosquitoes than it is.  After people put eastern mosquitofish in a body of water, there may be an algal bloom because the eastern mosquitofish eats or kills all the fish that usually eat the algae.

This fish likes to eat frog eggs and tadpoles.  It is one reason why the green and golden bell frog is endangered in Australia and the Chiricahua leopard frog in Arizona. 

The fish has 50-300 eggs at a time.  The eggs stay inside the female's body until they hatch.  It takes the new fish two months to become adults.  Eastern mosquitofish can do this several times each year.

The western mosquitofish G. affinis and eastern mosquitofish G. holbrooki used to both be called G. affinis because people thought they were the same species.  They are not.  According to the IUCN Global Invasive Species Database, most records in Australia that say "G. affinis" really refer to G. holbrooki.

[[Elizabethan collar]]

An Elizabethan collar, also called a, e-collar, lampshade or cone of shame is a piece of equipment used in veterinary medicine. They stop the animal from licking or biting its body and from scratching or touching its head with its feet.

[[For Your Eyes Only (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s spy movies, 1981 action movies, James Bond movies, Movies with underwater settings, Movies set in Greece, Movies set in Italy, Movies set in Spain, Movies set in North America, Roger Moore, Movies directed by John Glen

For Your Eyes Only is a 1981 British spy action movie directed by John Glen and is the 12th movie in the James Bond franchise. It was based on the short story by Ian Fleming and starring Roger Moore, Topol, Lynn-Holly Johnson, Julian Glover, Michael Gothard, Cassandra Harris, John Wyman, Desmond Llewelyn, Lois Maxwell, Charles Dance, Geoffrey Keen, Jack Hedley. It was distributed by United Artists and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1982. Sheena Easton sings the title song of the movie.

[[Mimi Soltysik]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, 2020 deaths, 2016 United States presidential candidates, American political activists, Deaths from liver cancer, Politicians from Pennsylvania, Socialists

Emidio "Mimi" Soltysik (October 30, 1974 – June 28, 2020) was an American socialist political activist. He was a member of the Socialist Party USA. He was the party's nominee for president of the United States in the 2016 election alongside Angela Nicole Walker, who was the party's vice-presidential nominee.

Soltysik was born in Reading, Pennsylvania. He died of liver cancer on June 28, 2020, at the age of 45.

[[Simonetta Sommaruga]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Presidents of the Swiss Confederation

Simonetta Myriam Sommaruga (born 14 May 1960) is a Swiss politician. She was the President of the Swiss Confederation from 1 January 2020 until 31 December 2020. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party.

Sommaurga has been a Member of the Federal Council since 2010. She was Vice President of the Federal Council for the year 2014. In 2015, she was President of the Swiss Confederation. 

[[Flavio Cotti]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Switzerland, Presidents of the Swiss Confederation

Flavio Cotti (18 October 1939 – 16 December 2020) was a Swiss politician. He was born in Prato-Sornico, Switzerland.

He was elected to the Federal Council of Switzerland on 10 December 1986. He retired on 30 April 1999. He was a member of the Christian Democratic People's Party of Switzerland. 

He was President of the Confederation twice, first in 1991 and then again in 1998.

Cotti died on 16 December 2020 of COVID-19 in Locarno, Switzerland at the age of 81.

[[Philip Latham]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, British movie actors, British television actors, British stage actors, Actors from Essex

Charles Philip Latham (17 January 1929 – 20 June 2020) was a British actor. He was born in Essex, England. One of his most famous movie roles was as Dracula's sinister servant Klove in Hammer's 1966 movie Dracula, Prince of Darkness. He was also known for his television role as Willy Izard in the BBC series The Troubleshooters (1965–72).

Latham died on 20 June 2020, aged 91.

[[Pete Carr]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, American rock guitarists, Record producers, Musicians from Florida, Businesspeople from Florida, People from Daytona Beach, Florida

Jesse Willard "Pete" Carr (April 22, 1950 – June 27, 2020) was an American guitarist and record producer. Carr was born in Daytona Beach, Florida.

Carr worked with Joan Baez, Luther Ingram, Bob Seger, Joe Cocker, Boz Scaggs, Paul Simon, The Staple Singers, Rod Stewart, Barbra Streisand, Wilson Pickett, Hank Williams, Jr., among many others, over the past forty years.

Carr co-produced Seger's Stranger in Town album which featured the hit "Old Time Rock and Roll".

Carr died on June 27, 2020 in Florence, Alabama at the age of 70.

[[Boz Scaggs]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, American singer-songwriters, American rock singers, American rock guitarists, American soul singers, American soul musicians, American blues singers, American blues musicians, American jazz singers, American jazz musicians, Singers from Ohio, Musicians from Ohio, Singers from Texas, Musicians from Texas, People from Plano, Texas, People from Canton, Ohio

William Royce "Boz" Scaggs (born June 8, 1944) is an American singer-songwriter, and guitarist. He became known for his series of albums in the late 1970s, and songs "Lido Shuffle" and "Lowdown" from Silk Degrees (1976). They peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard 200.

[[Bob Seger]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, American rock singers, American blues singers, American pop singers, American rock guitarists, American blues musicians, American pop musicians, American singer-songwriters, American pianists, Singers from Detroit, Michigan, Musicians from Detroit, Michigan, Writers from Detroit, Michigan

Robert Clark Seger (ˈ, born May 6, 1945) is an American singer-songwriter and musician. His breaking through was with his first album, Ramblin' Gamblin' Man. 

In 1973, he put together the Silver Bullet Band, with a group of Detroit-area musicians, with whom he became most successful on the national level with the album Live Bullet (1976).

Seger has sold more than 75 million records worldwide, making him one of the world's best-selling artists of all time. Seger was honored into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2004 and the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2012.

The movie stars are Gerard Butler, Morgan Freeman, Jada Pinkett Smith, Lance Reddick, Tim Blake Nelson, Piper Perabo, Nick Nolte, and Danny Huston. 

The movie was released in the United States on August 23, 2019, by Lionsgate. It received mixed reviews from critics. It made $147.5 million worldwide.

The Janitor (Nicolas Cage) is a poor person who is tricked into a janitor job at Wally's Wonderland. However, at his job, it is filled with violent and murderous robots.

His first big role came in the 1984 cult comedy movie Hardbodies, in which he played Scotty Palmer. His other big movie was the 1988 cult classic Killer Klowns from Outer Space. Other movie roles include appearances in Mach 2 (2001) and Follow the Prophet (2009).

[[Adrian Devine]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Deaths from lung cancer, Atlanta Braves players, Texas Rangers players, People from Galveston, Texas, Sportspeople from Texas

Paul Adrian Devine (December 2, 1951 – June 27, 2020) was an American baseball pitcher. He played seven seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB).  He played for for the Atlanta Braves and Texas Rangers from 1973 until 1980.  He batted and threw right-handed and was a relief pitcher. He was born in Galveston, Texas.

Devine survived tongue cancer twice. He died from brain and lung cancer on June 27, 2020 at the age of 68.

[[FC Politehnica Iași (1945)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s establishments in Romania, 1945 establishments in Europe, 2010 disestablishments in Europe, Romanian football clubs

Fotbal Club Politehnica Iași (po.liˈteh.nika ˈjaʃʲ), commonly known as Politehnica Iași or simply Poli Iași, was a Romanian football club from the city of Iași, Iași County.

The team was named after the Gheorghe Asachi Technical University of Iași. The team was founded in 1945. Its home stadium was the Stadionul Emil Alexandrescu, where it played in blue and white until being dissolved in 2010.

The club was created as Sportul Studențesc Iași by a group of students on 27 April 1945, and first received the name of Politehnica one month later (Asociația Sportivă Politehnica Iași).

[[FCM Dunărea Galați]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Romania, 1970 establishments in Europe, 2010s disestablishments in Europe, 2014 disestablishments, Romanian football clubs

Dunărea Galați was a Romanian professional football club from Galați, Galați County, south-east Romania. It was founded in 1970. The club was dissolved in 2014.

[[Giuseppe Matarrese]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Italian Roman Catholics, Bishops

Giuseppe Matarrese (3 June 1934 – 27 June 2020) was an Italian Roman Catholic bishop. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1959. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Suburbicarian Diocese of Frascati, Italy, from 1989 to 2009.

Matarrese died on 27 June 2020, aged 86.

[[Mihai Romilă]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Romanian footballers

Mihai Romilă (1 October 1950 – 27 June 2020) was a Romanian football midfielder.

Romilă played 18 matches at international level for Romania, including appearances at Euro 1976 and 1980 qualifiers and at the World Cup 1978 qualifiers. Romilă also played one game for Romania's Olympic team at the 1976 Summer Olympics qualifiers.

[[Sander Schnitger]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Generals, People from Rotterdam

Alexander "Sander" Schnitger (November 11, 1958 – June 27, 2020) was a Dutch general in the Royal Netherlands Air Force. He was Commander of the Royal Netherlands Air Force from 2012 to 2016. Schnitger was born in Rotterdam. Schnitger was appointed Commander of Volkel Air Base in 2005. Three years later, in 2008, he was promoted to Air commodore and appointed Director of Operations at the Air Force Staff of the Royal Netherlands Air Force.

Schnitger died on June 27, 2020 in The Hague from a short-illness at the age of 61.

[[Joe Bugel]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, American football linebackers, American football coaches, College football coaches, Sportspeople from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Joseph John Bugel (March 10, 1940 – June 28, 2020) was an American football coach and college player. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.  Although he was twice a head coach in the National Football League (NFL). He was one of the great offensive line coaches in NFL history. He was known for coaching Phoenix Cardinals, San Diego Chargers, Oakland Raiders and Washington Redskins.

Bugel died on June 28, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Jerry Markbreit]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Sportspeople from Chicago

Jerry Markbreit (born March 23, 1935) is a former American football referee in the National Football League (NFL) for 23 seasons. He became one of the best known referees in the game.  Markbreit officiated football games for 43 seasons.  From 1965 to 1975, Markbreit officiated college football games in the Big Ten Conference. 

[[Ben Dreith]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, Sportspeople from Colorado, Living people

Ben Dreith (born February 1, 1925) is a former American professional football on-field official. He worked from 1960 to 1969 in the American Football League (AFL) and from 1970 to 1990 in the NFL. He was a three-sport athlete at the University of Northern Colorado.

[[FK Inter Bratislava]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 establishments in Europe, Football clubs, Football in Slovakia, Bratislava

FK Inter Bratislava (ˈintɛɾ ˈbɾatislaʋa) is a Slovak football club based in Bratislava. They play its home matches at this moment at the stadium in Stupava. The club will be competing in 2. liga, the second tier in the Slovak football league system, after winning 3. liga Bratislava in the 2016–17 season.

[[FC Viktoria Plzeň]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 establishments in Europe, Czech football clubs

Football Club Viktoria Plíseň (ˈvɪktorja ˈpl̩zɛɲ) is a Czech professional football club based in Plzeň. They play in the Czech First League, the top division of football in the country.

As runners-up in the 1970–71 Czechoslovak Cup, the club gained the right to play in the following season's Cup Winners' Cup, as winners Spartak Trnava also won the championship and played in the European Cup. 

In 2010, they played in the UEFA Europa League after winning the 2009–10 Czech Cup.

[[Bank of Ceylon]]

CATEGORIES: Banks, Sri Lanka

Bank of Ceylon is a state-owned, major commercial bank in Sri Lanka. Its head office is located in an iconic cylindrical building in Colombo. The Bank has a network of 628 branches, 689 ATMs machines, 123 CDM network and 15 loan centres. 

In addition to the local presence, the bank maintains an off-shore banking unit in the head office in Colombo, and three branches in Malé, Chennai and Seychelles, and subsidiary in London.

[[Yu Lan]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese movie actors

Yu Lan (于蓝; 3 June 1921 – 28 June 2020) was a Chinese movie actress. In 1961, Yu won the award for Best Actress at the 2nd Moscow International Film Festival for her role in A Revolutionary Family. 

She died in Beijing on 28 June 2020, aged 99.

[[Tian Zhuangzhuang]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, Chinese movie directors, Chinese movie producers, Chinese movie actors, People from Beijing

Tian Zhuangzhuang (田壮壮; born April 1952) is a Chinese movie director, producer and actor.

Tian's early career were mainly avant-garde documentary movies such as On the Hunting Ground (1985) and The Horse Thief (1986). His movie The Blue Kite (1993), was so controversial he was forced to exile from the movie business. He later directed The Go Master (2006) and the historical action movie The Warrior and the Wolf (2009).

[[All-China Women's Federation]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in China, 1949 establishments in Asia, Political organizations based in Asia

The All-China Women's Federation (s), also known as the ACWF, is a women's rights organization created in China on 24 March 1949. The organization was created to empower women. 

[[Shen Jilan]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stomach cancer, Chinese politicians

Shen Jilan (申纪兰; 29 December 1929 – 28 June 2020) was a Chinese politician. She was a member of the Communist Party of China. She was elected to the 1st National People's Congress in 1954, and had been re-elected for all the subsequent sittings of the National People's Congress over the next 65 years. She was known as the world's longest serving congresswoman.

Shen died on 28 June 2020 at the age of 90, from stomach cancer

[[Nicola Quarta]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Italian politicians

Nicola Quarta (23 September 1927 – 27 June 2020) was an Italian politician. Quarta was born in Campi Salentina, Italy. and later served as its mayor for two terms. Quarta was a member of the Christian Democracy. 

He was a prefect until 1970, when he left office to run for the newly created Apulia regional council. Quarta was President of Apulia between 1978 and 1983. He was a member of the Chamber of Deputies until 1992. Quarta retired from politics in 1995.

Quarta died on 27 June 2020, aged 92.

[[Arnie Ginsburg]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, American DJs, Musicians from Boston, Massachusetts, Businesspeople from Boston, Massachusetts, People from Brookline, Massachusetts

Arnie W. "Woo-Woo" Ginsburg (August 5, 1926 – June 26, 2020) was an American disc jockey.

He worked for the Boston radio market from the mid-1950s to the 1970s.  Following this period, he became involved in the business side of radio as a business manager, president and owner of WVJV-TV.

He later was an executive with Pyramid Broadcasting and program manager of their Boston station WXKS/1430.

[[Ogunquit, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine

Ogunquit (oʊ oh) is a town in York County, Maine, United States. As of the 2010 census its population was 892.

[[Nilamber Dev Sharma]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Indian writers, Indian educators

Nilamber Dev Sharma (October 6, 1931 - June 23 2020) was an Indian scholar and writer. His works were of Dogri and English literature. He was best known for his work, An Introduction to Modern Dogri Literature. The first publication in English about Dogri literature. 

The Government of India honored Sharma in 2011, with the fourth highest civilian award of Padma Shri.

[[A Walk with Love and Death]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 drama movies, 1960s romantic drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by John Huston

A Walk with Love and Death is a 1969 American romantic drama movie directed by John Huston (who also stars) and based on the 1961 novel of the same name by Hans Koning. It stars Anjelica Huston, Assi Dayan, Robert Lang, Anthony Higgins, John Hallam, Anthony Nicholls, George Murcell, Michael Gough, Guy Deghy and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Liam Treadwell]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, 2020 deaths, English sportspeople, People from West Sussex

Liam Treadwell (3 January 1986spnd23 June 2020) was an English National Hunt jockey. He won over 300 races between 2009 and 2019. He won the 2009 Grand National on Mon Mome at odds of 100/1. He also won the United House Gold Cup, Byrne Group Plate, and Grand Sefton Steeplechase races. He was born in Arundel, West Sussex.

Treadwell died on 23 June 2020 in Billingsley, Shropshire at the age of 34.

[[Pat Stark]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, American football quarterbacks, American football coaches, College basketball coaches, Sportspeople from New York

Peter G. "Pat" Stark (April 8, 1930 – June 19, 2020) was an American college football player and coach. He was the head football coach at the University of Rochester from 1969 to 1983. He had a record of 69–64–3. As a quarterback at Syracuse University, Stark was drafted by the Pittsburgh Steelers in the 1954 NFL Draft. He was also a member for the Syracuse men's basketball team from 1951 to 1953. He was born in Penfield, New York.

Stark died on June 19, 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Victor Feldbrill]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Conductors, Canadian musicians, Violinists

Victor Feldbrill, CAN (April 4, 1924 – June 17, 2020) was a Canadian conductor and violinist. He was born in Toronto. Feldbrill performed as a violinist in the Toronto Symphony Orchestra from 1949 to 1956. From 1958 to 1968, he was the principal conductor of the Winnipeg Symphony Orchestra. 

In 1967 he conducted the Toronto Philharmonia in a recording of the album Heritage, which featured music by Canadian composers.

In 1969 he directed the CBC Festival Orchestra.

From 1973 to 1978, he was the resident conductor of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra. In 1974, he founded the Toronto Symphony Youth Orchestra and was its conductor until 1978.

Feldbrill died on June 17, 2020 in Toronto, at the age of 96.

[[Abhishek Kumar Ambar]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 2000 births, Urdu poets, People from Uttar Pradesh, Indian poets

Abhishek Kumar Ambar is an Urdu and Hindi poet and founder of Garhwali Kavitakosh. He is a disciple of Rajendar Nath Rehbar and his ghazals have been recorded by Ghazal Srinivas.   

[[Gordon H. Bower]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pulmonary fibrosis, American psychologists, Scientists from Ohio, Writers from Ohio

Gordon Howard Bower (December 30, 1932 – June 17, 2020) was an American cognitive psychologist. He studied human memory, language comprehension, emotion, and behavior modification. 

He held the A. R. Lang Emeritus Professorship at Stanford University. 

He was voted number 42 in the list of most notable psychologists of the 20th century, published by the Review of General Psychology. 

He was awarded the National Medal of Science in 2005.

Bower died on June 17, 2020 at his home in Stanford, California from pulmonary fibrosis at the age of 87.

Scio is a village in Harrison County, Ohio, United States. The population was 763 at the 2010 census.

[[Valério Breda]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Italian Roman Catholics, Brazilian people, Bishops

Valério Breda (24 January 1945 – 16 June 2020) was an Italian-born Brazilian Roman Catholic bishop. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1973. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Penedo, Brazil, from 1997 until his death in 2020.

Breda died on 16 June 2020, aged 75.

[[Phil Takahashi]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian educators, Canadian Olympians, Cancer deaths in Canada, Sportspeople from Toronto

Philip Masato Takahashi (June 12, 1957 – June 15, 2020) was a Canadian judoka. He represented his native country at the Summer Olympics (1984 and 1988). He twice won a bronze medal at the Pan American Games.

He ran Takahashi Dojo in Ottawa, Ontario. He taught Judo, Karate and other forms of martial arts. He also taught both English and Physical Education at Confederation High School (Ottawa). 

Takahashi died of cancer in Ottawa on June 15, 2020 at the age of 63.

[[Adebayo Osinowo]]

Adebayo Sikiru Osinowo (November 28, 1955 – June 15, 2020) also known as Pepper was a Nigerian businessman and politician. He was a member of the Lagos State House of Representatives. Until his death, he was Senator representing Lagos East at the 9th Nigerian National Assembly.

Osinowo died on June 15, 2020 from COVID-19 in Lagos, aged 64.

[[Robert S. Molaro]]

Robert S. Molaro (June 29, 1960 – June 15, 2020) was an American politician. He was a Democratic member of both houses of the Illinois General Assembly. In 1993, he was elected to the Illinois Senate. In 2003, he was elected to the Illinois House of Representatives. He retired in 2009. Molaro was born in Chicago.

Molaro died in Chicago from pancreatic cancer on June 15, 2020 at the age of 69.

[[Fabrizio Mioni]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian voice actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Rome, Actors from Los Angeles, California

Fabrizio Mioni (September 23, 1930 – June 8, 2020) was an Italian-American actor. He was born in Rome. Mioni was known for his roles as Renaud in Roland the Mighty (1956), Jason in Hercules (1958) and as Armand in Get Yourself a College Girl (1964).

[[Lynika Strozier]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, 2020 deaths, Researchers, American educators, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Scientists from Chicago, Scientists from Birmingham, Alabama

Lynika Strozier (August 28, 1984 – June 7, 2020) was an American researcher and scientist. She was born in Birmingham, Alabama. Her career began when she started to work at Chicago's Field Museum, as a student intern. She was known for being able to work with DNA from particularly small and difficult biological samples.

She spent most of her scientific career at the Field Museum. In 2019 she started working as an adjunct professor at Malcolm X College. 

Strozier died on June 7, 2020 in Chicago from COVID-19, aged 35.

[[Floyd Lee]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American blues musicians, American blues singers, American guitarists, Musicians from Mississippi, Singers from Mississippi, Musicians from Chicago, Singers from Chicago

Floyd Lee, also known as Theodore Williams (August 20, 1933 – June 7, 2020), was an American blues musician. He was best known for his  performances of blues music in and around New York's subway stations for almost 30 years. Although best known for his passionate street performing in New York, in Lee's later years he recorded four albums in the 2000s on the Amogla Records label. 

Lee died on June 7, 2020 at a hospital in Columbus, Ohio of heart failure at the age of 86.

John Eldon Zook  (September 24, 1947 – June 6, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was born in Garden City, Kansas. He was a defensive end for 12 seasons in the National Football League (NFL). He played for the St. Louis Cardinals and the Atlanta Falcons. Zook played college football for the University of Kansas.

Gerard Milton Earnhart (April 1, 1918 – June 6, 2020) was an American politician and broadcast journalist. He was a Democratic member of the Arkansas House of Representatives and Arkansas Senate from the years of 1959 to 1980. He was born in Pine Lawn, Missouri.

Earnhart died on June 6, 2020 in Fort Smith, Arkansas at the age of 102.

[[Ivan Kostov]]

Ivan Yordanov Kostov (Иван Йорданов Костов) (born 23 December 1949) is a Bulgarian politician. He was the 47th Prime Minister of Bulgaria in office from May 1997 to July 2001. He was leader of the Union of Democratic Forces (UDF) between December 1994 and July 2001.

[[Ron Larrieu]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, American track and field athletes, Sportspeople from San Francisco

Gilbert Ronald Larrieu (May 23, 1937 – June 1, 2020), known as Ron Larrieu, was an American long-distance runner. He competed in the men's 10,000 metres at the 1964 Summer Olympics. He was born in San Francisco. He was a two time national champion in cross country, in 1965 and 1966.

Larrieu died on June 1, 2020 at the age of 83.

[[Art Miller Jr.]]

Arthur "Art" Miller Jr. (July 11, 1946 – June 25, 2020) was a Democratic politician. He was a member of the Michigan Senate from 1975 through 2002 representing a portion of Macomb County. From April 1985 through 1996, he was the Democratic leader in the chamber. Miller Jr. was born in Detroit, Michigan.

Miller Jr. died on June 25, 2020 in Royal Oak, Michigan from lung cancer at the age of 73.

[[Macomb County, Michigan]]

Macomb County is a county located in the eastern portion of the U.S. state of Michigan and is part of northern Metro Detroit. As of the 2010 census, the population was 840,978. It is the third-most populous county in the state. The county seat is Mt. Clemens.
