Mount Clemens is a city in the U.S. state of Michigan. The population was 16,314 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Macomb County.

[[Metro Detroit]]

CATEGORIES: Detroit, Michigan, Metropolitan areas of the United States

The Detroit metropolitan area, often referred to as Metro Detroit, is a major metropolitan area in the U.S. State of Michigan, consisting of the city of Detroit and its surrounding area.

The area covers parts of the counties of Macomb, Oakland, and Wayne.

[[Kingdom of Kotte]]

The Kingdom of Kotte (Sinhala: කෝට්ටේ රාජධානිය Kottay Rajadhaniya), centered on Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte , was a kingdom that flourished in  Sri Lanka during the 15th century.

[[Medicaid]]

CATEGORIES: United States

Medicaid in the United States is a federal and state program that helps with medical costs for some people with limited income and resources. Medicaid also offers benefits not normally covered by Medicare, including nursing home care and personal care services. The program is jointly funded by the federal government and individual states. It is operated at the state level which means that coverage and administration vary greatly from state to state. It is available only to individuals and families who meet specific income-based criteria.

Medicaid is the largest source of funding for medical and health-related services for people with low income in the United States, providing free health insurance to 74 million low-income and disabled people (23% of Americans) as of 2017.

Under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) of 2010, states had the option to expand Medicaid coverage to nearly all low-income people under the age of 65. Eligibility for children was extended to at least 133% of the federal poverty level, and states now have the option to cover adults with income levels at or below 133% of the federal poverty level. The Affordable Care Act (ACA) expanded coverage so that more Americans have access to health insurance—which includes mental health treatment coverage. Under the ACA, both mental and behavioral health disorders are covered similarly to physical health disorders. This includes the treatment of substance use disorders.

[[Satyatma Tirtha]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Religious leaders, 1973 births, Hindu saints

Sri Satyatma Tirtha, is an Indian Hindu philosopher, guru and scholar. He is the Swamiji of the Sri Uttaradi Matha, a Matha belonging to the Dvaita school of philosophy, founded by Sri Madhvacharya. Sri Satyatma Tirtha is the 42nd in the lineage of the Uttaradi Matha, starting from Madhvacharya. Satyatma Tirtha was born in Mumbai, India. He is the founder of Vishwa Madhwa Maha Parishat.

[[Portuguese Ceylon]]

Portuguese Ceylon (Ceilão Português, Sinhala: පෘතුගීසි ලංකාව Puruthugisi Lankawa, Tamil: போர்த்துக்கேய இலங்கை Porthukeya Ilankai) is the name given to the territory on Ceylon, modern-day Sri-Lanka, controlled by the Portuguese Empire between 1597 and 1658.

Portuguese presence in the island lasted from 1505 to 1658. Their arrival was largely accidental, and the Portuguese sought control of commerce, rather than territory. The Portuguese were later drawn into the internal politics of the island with the political upheaval of the Wijayaba Kollaya, and used these internal divisions to their advantage during the Sinhalese–Portuguese War, first in an attempt to control the production of valuable cinnamon and later of the entire island. Direct Portuguese rule did not begin until after the death of Dharmapala of Kotte, who died without an heir, and had bequeathed the Kingdom of Kotte to the Portuguese monarch in 1580. That allowed the Portuguese sufficient claim to the Kingdom of Kotte upon Dharmapala's death in 1597. Portuguese rule began with much resistance by the local population.

Eventually, the Kingdom of Kandy sought help from the Dutch East India Company, with whom they initially entered into agreement. After the collapse of the Iberian economy in 1627, the Dutch–Portuguese War saw the Dutch conquest of most of Portugal's Asian colonies - Ceylon included, between 1638 and 1658. Nevertheless, elements of Portuguese culture from this colonial period remain in Sri Lanka.

[[Medicare (United States)]]

CATEGORIES: Companies of the United States

Medicare is a national health insurance program in the United States. It began in 1965 under the Social Security Administration (SSA) by Lyndon B. Johnson and now administered by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS). It gives health care insurance for Americans aged 65 and older, people with End-Stage Renal Disease and also for some younger people with disability. Medicare consists of three parts:

Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance): Covers inpatient hospital care, skilled nursing facility care, hospice, and some home health care.

Medicare Part B (Medical Insurance): Covers doctor office visits and services, outpatient care, medical supplies, and preventative care and services.

Medicare Part D (prescription drug coverage): Covers the cost of prescription drugs, flu shots, and vaccines.

[[Dutch Ceylon]]

CATEGORIES: Colonialism

Dutch Ceyoln was an entity that existed from 1640 to 1796. It is called  ලන්දේසි ලංකාව  si in Sinhala. In the early 17th century, Sri Laka (which was called Ceylon at the time), was divided between the Portugese, and several local kingdoms. The kingdoms were fighting agains each other very often. Although the Portuguese were not winning the war, their rule was rather burdensome to the people of those areas controlled by them. At some point, the king of Kandy asked the Durch for help. The  Dutch East India Company ran the country. Even though they managed to control large aras near the coast, they did not countrol the mountain areas and the Kandxan kingdom in the center of the iland.  The Durch inteerest in Ceylon was to have a stornghold against the Iberians (Spanish and Portugese) at the time.

[[Cal Cunningham]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, American lawyers, American military people, State legislators of the United States, People from Winston-Salem, North Carolina, Politicians from North Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians

James Calvin Cunningham III (born August 6, 1973) is an American politician, lawyer, and veteran. He was the North Carolina State Senator from the 23rd district from 2001 to 2003. He is a member of the Democratic Party.

He had an unsuccessful primary campaign for the United States Senate in the 2010 election. In 2020, Cunningham became the Democratic nominee in the 2020 Senate election.

In October 2020, it was revealed that Cunningham had an affair early in the year and sent sexual text messages to his mistress. This was controversial and affected his polling lead against U.S. Senator Thom Tillis weeks before the election. Cunningham lost the election to Tillis on November 10.

[[British Ceylon]]

Ceylon (Sinhala: බ්‍රිතාන්‍ය ලංකාව, Brithānya Laṃkāva; Tamil: பிரித்தானிய இலங்கை, Birithaniya Ilangai) was the British Crown colony of present-day Sri Lanka between 1815 and 1948. Initially the area it covered did not include the Kingdom of Kandy, which was a protectorate, but from 1817 to 1948 the British possessions included the whole island of Ceylon, now the nation of Sri Lanka.

Among Us is an American science-fiction social deduction video game made by Innersloth. Inc. It was released for iOS and Android on June 15, 2018, for PC on Steam on November 16, 2018. It was also released on itch.io on August 17, 2018. Among Us follows a crew being killed one at a time by an Impostor. The game got very popular in late 2020 because many Twitch streamers and YouTubers have played it.

[[Koryakskaya]]

CATEGORIES: Volcanoes, Geography of Russia

Koryakskaya Sopka or Korkatsky is a volcano on the Kamtchatka penisula in the Russian Far East. This volcano is 11300 high. The peak of the volcano has a modern crater, 590-650 feet in diameter. The volcano is located only 22 from the territory’s capital, Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky and contributes to the panoramic views from the city.

[[Acute respiratory distress syndrome]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a type of respiratory failure caused by a massive widespread inflammation in the lungs. Symptoms include shortness of breath, rapid breathing, and bluish skin color. For those who survive, a short life span is common as a result.

Causes may include sepsis, pancreatitis, trauma, pneumonia, and aspiration. 

[[Owosso, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan

Owosso is the largest city in Shiawassee County in the U.S. state of Michigan. The population was 15,194 at the 2010 census.  The city is mostly surrounded by Owosso Township on the east.  The city was named after Chief Wosso, an Ojibwe leader of the Shiawassee area.

[[Shiawassee County, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: 1837 establishments in Michigan, Michigan counties

Shiawassee ˌ is a county located in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population was 70,648. The county seat is Corunna, and the largest city in the county is Owosso.

[[Corunna, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan, County seats in Michigan

Corunna (k CORE-UN-NUH) is a city and county seat of Shiawassee County in the U.S. state of Michigan.  The population was 3,497 at the 2010 census.  The city is surrounded by Caledonia Charter Township and is slight east of the city of Owosso.

[[Owosso Township, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Michigan

Owosso Township, formally named Owosso Charter Township, is a charter township of Shiawassee County in the U.S. state of Michigan.  The population was 4,821 at the 2010 census.  The township borders the city of Owosso.

[[Felipe Franco Munhoz]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, Brazilian writers, People from São Paulo

Felipe Franco Munhoz (born 4 March 1990 in São Paulo) is a Brazilian writer.

He graduated from Federal University of Paraná. He  participated in important literary events, such as the Macau Literary Festival and Printemps Littéraire Brésilien.

[[Lower Peninsula of Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Michigan, Peninsulas

The Lower Peninsula of Michigan – also known as Lower Michigan – is the southern and less elevated of the two major landmasses that make up the U.S. state of Michigan, the other being the Upper Peninsula. It is surrounded by water on all sides except its southern border, which it shares with Indiana and Ohio.

Although the Upper Peninsula is commonly referred to as "the U.P.", it is uncommon for the Lower Peninsula to be called "the L.P." 

[[Wheaton, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota, County seats in Minnesota

Wheaton is a city in Traverse County, Minnesota, United States.  The population was 1,424 at the 2010 census.  It is the county seat.

[[Shelby Charter Township, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Michigan

Shelby Charter Township, officially the Charter Township of Shelby, is a charter township and census-designated place located in Macomb County in the U.S. state of Michigan. It is a suburb of Detroit. As of the 2000 census, the township had a total population of 65,159. Shelby Charter Township is one of the fastest growing communities in Metro Detroit.

[[Chelsea, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan

Chelsea is a city in Washtenaw County in the U.S. state of Michigan. The population was 4,944 at the 2010 census.

[[Rochester, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan

Rochester is a city in Oakland County in the U.S. state of Michigan. About 12,711 lived here since 2010.  It is a northern suburb of Metro Detroit. It is located about 16 north of the city of Detroit.

[[Léonor Serraille]]

Léonor Serraille  (born in Lyon) is a French director and screenwriter .

She won a César Award for Best First Feature Film, Caméra d'Or , and Lumières Award for Best First Film .

[[Danielle Brisebois (volleyball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Canadian volleyball players

Danielle Brisebois (born August 12, 1994) is a Canadian volleyball player. She is part of the Canadian women's national volleyball team. She competed at the 2015 FIVB World Grand Prix, 2016 FIVB World Grand Prix, and 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix.

She played for University of British Columbia's women's volleyball team, Nyíregyházathe, and Schwarz-Weiss Erfurt.

[[Stephanie McCrummen]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners, George Polk Award winners

Stephanie McCrummen is an American journalist. She won a George Polk Award and Pulitzer Prize in Investigative Reporting.

She graduated from University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Columbia University.

She worked for The Washington Post.

[[AS-Val]]

CATEGORIES: Assault rifles, Soviet Union

The AS-Val is a rifle designed (created) by the Soviets. It has a built-in suppresor. The special rifle (AS) development began in the first half of the late 1980s in the Central Research Institute of Precision Engineering, in the city of Klimovsk part of the Moscow region. The lead designer of the rifle is Pyotr Serdyukov.

TsNIITochMash (Central Institute for Precision Machine Building) developed it in 1987. Since 1987, the Soviet Army and the KGB used it in their arsenal. Russian Spetsnaz special forces and some divisions of the Russian Army also use it.

The rifle is expensive and there are not many AS-Vals available. It is not used often according to many Russian Spetsnaz operators. It is used during special operations by either sabotage or reconnaissance units deployed behind enemy lines. 

The AS Val and VSS are very effective. Some Russian army and special forces units, and Moscow’s intelligence and security forces still use it. Forces used the rifles during the last years of the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. They were also important in the Chechen wars and the conflict in Georgia.

Most recently, Russia used the weapon during military operations in Crimea and Syria.

[[Qian Jingwen]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 births, Chinese volleyball players, Living people

Qian Jingwen (born  11 May 1998) is a Chinese volleyball player. She played for the Chinese national team. She played at the 2015 FIVB Volleyball Girls' U18 World Championship, 2016 Asian Women's U19 Volleyball Championship, 2017 Montreux Volley Masters, and 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix.

She played for Shandong women's volleyball team.

She played for the University of Minnesota's women's volleyball team. Allianz Stuttgart, and Lardini Filottrano.

[[Mosquitofish]]

CATEGORIES: Fish

The mosquitofish (Gambusia affinis), also known as the mosquito fish, western mosquitofish, western gambusia, or live-bearing tooth carp, is a fish that belongs to the Poeciliidae family.  It is from the southern and midwestern United States and east coast of Mexico. Human beings brought it to many other parts of the world, such as Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and Australia, where it has caused problems as an invasive specie.  Some scientists say that the western mosquitofish has had the largest effect on the environment of any fish in Poeciliidae.

The adult male western mosquitofish grows to 4 cm and the female to 7 cm. It has a round tail fin. It eats algae, insects, and other invertebrates.  It can eat more than its own body weight every day.  It can live in water that is twice as salty as seawater.  It can live in water as hot as 43°C.

In the early 20th century, people brought the western mosquitofish to other places because they thought it would eat mosquitoes and their larvae, but this did not work.  Sometimes there were more mosquitoes than before:  The western mosquitofish ate, outcompeted or killed other fish that were eating mosquitoes.  It sometimes killed fish that were better at controlling mosquitoes than it was.  It also ate some of the insects that had been eating the mosquitos and larvae.  It also ate zooplankton, which left more food for the mosquito larvae.

The western mosquitofish can kill larger fish by attacking their fins and eating their eggs and babies.  It eats smaller fish.  It likes to eat frog eggs and tadpoles. After people put western mosquitofish in a body of water, there may be an algal bloom because the western mosquitofish eats or kills all the fish that usually eat the algae. The western mosquitofish is one reason why many other species are endangered.  Some of the important ones are the Railroad Valley springfish (Crenichthys baileyi) in Nevada, the Sonoran topminnow (Poeciliopsis occidentalis) in Arizona, and the damselfly in Hawaii.

The western mosquitofish usually has 60 eggs at a time, but it can have as many as 300 at a time.  The eggs stay inside the female's body until they hatch.

The western mosquitofish G. affinis and eastern mosquitofish G. holbrooki used to both be called G. affinis because people thought they were the same species.  They are not.  According to the IUCN Global Invasive Species Database, most records in Australia that say "G. affinis" really refer to G. holbrooki.

[[Barilium]]

CATEGORIES: Iguanodonts

Barilium is a genus of iguanodontian dinosaur which was first described as a species of Iguanodon (I. dawsoni) by Richard Lydekker in 1888, the specific epithet honouring the discoverer Charles Dawson.

[[Pale frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The pale frog, pallid rocket frog, pale rocket frog or peach-sided rocket frog (Litoria pallida) is a frog from Australia. It lives in Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory.

The adult frog can grow to 4.0 cm long.  It is light gray in colour with some stripes.  It has yellow colour on its legs.  Its front feet have a little webbing and its hind feet have more webbing.

It lives in forests and grasslands and in caves and rocky places.

It lays eggs 50–350 eggs at a time in temporary bodies of water.  The tadpoles take 8 to 10 weeks to become frogs but sometimes they become frogs in as little as 5 weeks.

[[Lamborghini Urus]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s automobiles, 2020s automobiles, Lamborghini automobiles, Sport utility vehicles

The Lamborghini Urus is an SUV made by Lamborghini. It is powered by a twin-turbo V8 engine. It was built in 2017 and released in February 2018 for the 2018 model year.

[[Lamborghini LM002]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s automobiles, 1990s automobiles, Lamborghini automobiles, Sport utility vehicles

Lamborghini LM002 is a 4x4 that was made by Lamborghini from 1986 to 1993. This was unusual for Lamborghini, since the company was known for making sports cars. The LM002 was not the first off-road vehicle to be made by Lamborghini.  Two prototype vehicles, the Cheetah and the LM001, were made before the LM002. However, they were not successful. The LM002 is part of a series of vehicles known as the Lamborghini Militaria.

The Croods is a 2013 American computer-animated adventure comedy movie produced by DreamWorks Animation and distributed by 20th Century Fox. The movie was written and directed by Kirk DeMicco and Chris Sanders, and stars the voices of Nicolas Cage, Emma Stone, Ryan Reynolds, Catherine Keener, Clark Duke,  Cloris Leachman, and Randy Thom.

[[Al Wakrah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Asia, Qatar

Al Wakrah (الوكرة) is a city in Qatar. Al Wakrah's eastern edge is the shore of the Persian Gulf and Qatar's capital city Doha is situated north of the city. It is governed by Sheikh Abdulrahman bin Jassim Al Thani.  It was originally a small fishing and pearling village. Over the years, it evolved into a small city with a population of more than 80,000 and is currently considered to be the second-largest city in Qatar.

It has undergone extensive development and growth since the 21st century began while also being slowly merged by rapidly expanding Doha from the north. Notable milestones in the city's modern history include the May 2019 inauguration of Al Janoub Stadium, a stadium that will be used for the 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar, the opening of Al Wakrah Heritage Village in 2016, the Al Wakrah Main Road Project which is set to be completed in 2020, and the city's integration into the Doha Metro's Red Line.

Situated off the Persian Gulf to the east, Al Wakrah is approximately 15 km (9.3 mi) south of the capital city Doha, 72 km (45 mi) south of Al Khor, 21 km (13 mi) north of Mesaieed, 36 km (22 mi) southeast of Umm Salal Mohammed, and 100 km (62 mi) southeast of Dukhan.

The city has two public beaches and a mall named Ezdan Mall, which was completed in late 2016.

[[Doha Metro]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s establishments in Asia, 2019 establishments, Rapid transit systems, Transport in Asia, Qatar

The Doha Metro is a rapid transit system in Doha, Qatar's capital city. It became operational on 8 May 2019. It has three lines with an overall length of about 76 km and 37 stations.

The Doha Metro will have around 100 stations for the entire network when the project is finished.

[[Sky Riders]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 movies, 1970s action movies, 1970s adventure movies, American action movies, American adventure movies, Greek movies, Movies directed by Douglas Hickox

Sky Raiders (also known as Assault on the Forbidden Fortress) is a 1976 American Greek action adventure movie directed by Douglas Hickox and starring James Coburn, Susannah York, Robert Culp, Charles Aznavour, Harry Andrews, Zouzou, John Beck. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Mike Harrington]]

CATEGORIES: American businesspeople, Video game designers, Microsoft, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Mike Harrington is an American computer programmer. He is the co-founder of the video game development and digital distribution company Valve. Previously a game programmer at Dynamix and a designer on the Windows NT operating system at Microsoft, Harrington founded Valve in 1996 with Gabe Newell, another former Microsoft employee. He and Newell privately funded the development of Half-Life, which he also helped program.

On January 15, 2000, after the success of Half-Life, Harrington dissolved his partnership with Newell and left Valve to spend time with his wife. "At Microsoft you always wonder, 'Is it me being successful or is it Microsoft?' But with Half-Life I knew Gabe and I had built that product and company from scratch." According to Newell, Harrington did not want to risk another project after the success of Half-Life.

In 2006, Harrington co-founded Picnik with friend and former colleague Darrin Massena, which was later acquired by Google in March 2010. Harrington left Google in March 2011, and co-founded another company with Massena, called Catnip Labs, in January 2012. Harrington was the CTO at The Committee for Children from 2016-2018 and is now the CTO of Amplion.

[[Piqua, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio

Piqua (ˈ PIK) is a city in Miami County, southwest Ohio, United States, 27 miles north of Dayton. The population was 20,522 at the 2010 census.

[[Ministry of Health (Israel)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 establishments in Israel, Government of Israel

The Ministry of Health (מִשְׂרַד הַבְּרִיאוּת) is a ministry in the Israeli government. It is responsible for deciding the health policies for the Israel.

The present Health Minister is Nitzan Horowitz (Meretz).

[[PMRS]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 establishments in Asia, Non-profit organizations of Asia, Palestine

Palestinian Medical Relief Society (PMRS) is a community based non-profit health-organization in Palestine. It was established in 1979 by a group of Palestinian doctors and health professionals. Its main objective is to improve the overall physical, mental, and social well being of all Palestinians, irrespective of their racial, political, social, economic status.

[[Laura Hillman]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, German Jews, American Jews, Holocaust survivors

Laura Hillman (born Hannelore Wolff; October 16, 1923 – June 4, 2020) was a German-born American survivor of Holocaust concentration camps, including Auschwitz-Birkenau. She was also a Schindlerjude, who survived the Holocaust with the help of Oskar Schindler. 

In 2005, she published a young adult book about her experiences during the Holocaust which is titled i will plant you a lilac tree – a memoir of a Schindler's list survivor. She was born in Aurich, Ostfriesland, Germany.

Hillman died on June 4, 2020 in Rossmoor, California at the age of 96.

[[Rossmoor, California]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in California, Settlements in Orange County, California

Rossmoor is a planned census-designated place located in Orange County, California. As of the 2010 census, the CDP had a total population of 10,244, down from 10,298 at the 2000 census.

[[Noel Johnson (basketball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2020 deaths, College basketball coaches, American basketball players, Deaths from ovarian cancer, Sportspeople from Texas

Noel Dawn Johnson (December 1, 1972 – June 9, 2020) was an American basketball player and the head coach of the Midwestern State Mustangs women's basketball team. She played for the national championship Texas Tech Lady Raiders in 1993. She was born in Shamrock, Texas. She also coached Midwestern State Mustangs from 2009 to 2020.

Johnson died on June 9, 2020 from ovarian cancer, aged 47.

[[Shamrock, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Shamrock is a city in Wheeler County, Texas, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city had a total population of 1,910.

[[Peter E. Toschek]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, German educators, German physicists

Peter E. Toschek (18 April 1933 – 25 June 2020) was a German experimental physicist. He researched nuclear physics, quantum optics, and laser physics. He was known as an important scientist of laser spectroscopy. He was a professor at Hamburg University. Toschek was born in Hindenburg, Saxony-Anhalt.

Toschek died on 25 June 2020 in Hindenburg, aged 87.

[[Pierre-Antoine-Jean Bach]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, French Roman Catholics, Laotian people, Bishops

Pierre-Antoine-Jean Bach (29 July 1932 – 26 June 2020) was a French-born Laotian Roman Catholic bishop. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1959. He was the Roman Catholic bishop of the Apostolic Vicariate of Savannakhet. Laos, from 1971 to 1975.

Bach died on 26 June 2020, aged 87.

[[Tom Finn (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: Musicians from New York City, Singer-songwriters from New York City, American jazz singers, American pop singers, American jazz musicians, American pop musicians, American guitarists, American DJs, 2020 deaths, 1948 births

Thomas Joseph Finn (November 21, 1948 – June 27, 2020) was an American pop jazz singer-songwriter, guitarist and DJ.  He was a founding member of the 1960s baroque pop group The Left Banke.

Finn died on June 27, 2020 at the age of 71.

[[David Stronach]]

CATEGORIES: Scottish scientists, Archaeologists, 1931 births, 2020 deaths

David Bruce Stronach GBR  (1931 – 2020) was a British archeologist of ancient Iran and Iraq. He was an emeritus professor at the University of California, Berkeley. He was recipient of the 2004 Archaeological Institute of America (AIA) Gold Medal for "Distinguished Archaeological Achievement". Stronach was an expert on the city of Pasargadae.

Stronach died on June 27, 2020 at the age of 89.

[[Kim Bridgford]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, American poets, American critics, American educators, Writers from Illinois

Kim Bridgford (August 9, 1959 – June 28, 2020) was an American poet, writer, critic, and academic. 

In her poetry, she wrote mainly in traditional forms, particularly sonnets. She was the director of Poetry by the Sea: A Global Conference, created in 2014 and first held in May 2015. She directed the West Chester University Poetry Conference from 2010 through 2014. She was born in Coal Valley, Illinois. Bridgford started teaching at Fairfield University in Connecticut in 1989.

Bridgford died from cancer on June 28, 2020, at the age of 60, at a hospice care center in Bettendorf, Iowa.

[[John Kneebone]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, New Zealand people

John Thomas Kneebone NZL (1935 – 28 June 2020) was a New Zealand farming leader. He was elected as president of Federated Farmers in 1974. He was appointed to the Waitangi Tribunal in 1989. He was the inspiration behind the National Agricultural Fieldays in 1969.

In the 1988 New Year Honours, Kneebone was appointed a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George, for public services and services to agriculture. 

He died in Cambridge on 28 June 2020, aged 84.

[[Ingrid Roscoe]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Writers from Yorkshire

Dame Ingrid Mary Roscoe, DCVO, FSA (27 May 1944 – 28 June 2020) was an English writer on art. Roscoe was Lord Lieutenant of West Yorkshire from 2004 until 2018. Roscoe was editor-in-chief and co-author of A Biographical Dictionary of Sculptors in Britain, 1660–1851, published in November 2009. 

Roscoe died on 28 June 2020, aged 76.

[[Workum]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Friesland, Súdwest-Fryslân

Workum (Warkum, Wörkem) is a city located in the municipality of Súdwest-Fryslân in Friesland, Netherlands. It received city rights in 1374. It is one of the eleven cities of Friesland. It had a population of 4,435 in January 2017.

[[Museology]]

CATEGORIES: Museums

Museology or museum studies is the study of museums. It studies the history of museums and their role in society, as well as the activities they engage in. They also study other things about museums including curating, preservation, public programming, and education.

[[Bernhard van Haersma Buma]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Christian Democratic Appeal politicians, Christian Historical Union politicians, Dutch civil servants, Dutch historians, Dutch mayors, Politicians from Friesland, Writers from Friesland

Bernhardus “Bernhard” van Haersma Buma (23 March 1932 – 26 June 2020) was a Dutch politician and writer. He was a member of the Christian Historical Union (CHU) and later on of the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA). He was mayor of Workum and Sneek. He was born in Stavoren, Netherlands.

Buma died from a heart attack on 26 June 2020 at a hospital in Leeuwarden, Netherlands at the age of 88.

Bernhard van Haersma Buma is the father of CDA politician Sybrand van Haersma Buma.

[[Madeleine Juneau]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian historians, Canadian educators, Writers from Montreal

Madeleine Juneau (10 November 1945 – 26 June 2020) was a Canadian museologist and teacher. She was a member of the Congregation of Notre Dame of Montreal. She was awarded the Prix Gérard-Morisset in 2013. She was born in Saint-Augustin-de-Desmaures, Quebec.

Juneau died in Verdun, France on 26 June 2020, aged 74.

[[Rosemarie Müller-Streisand]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, German historians, German theologians, Writers from Berlin

Rosemarie Müller-Streisand (11 August 1923 – 26 June 2020) was a German church historian, theologian and teacher. In 1963 she became a professor and in 1969 she was a main person of church history at the Humboldt University in Berlin. She retired in 1983.

Müller-Streisand died in Berlin on 26 June 2020, aged 96.

[[Ernesto Marcel]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Boxers, Panamanian sportspeople

Ernesto Marcel (23 May 1948 – 29 June 2020) was a Panamanian professional boxer. He competed from 1966 to 1974. He held the WBA featherweight title from 1972 to 1974 and challenged for the WBC featherweight title in 1971. Marcel was born in Colón, Panama.

Marcel died on 29 June 2020 in Panama City, aged 72.

[[Benny Mardones]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, American singer-songwriters, American rock singers, American pop singers, Singers from Cleveland, Ohio, Writers from Cleveland, Ohio

Ruben Armand "Benny" Mardones (November 9, 1946 – June 29, 2020) was an American pop singer-songwriter. He was known for his hit single "Into the Night," which hit the Top 20 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart twice, in 1980 (#11) and again in 1989 (#20). He was born in Cleveland, Ohio.

Mardones died on June 29, 2020 at his home in Menifee, California from Parkinson's disease-related problems, aged 73.

Menifee is a city in Riverside County, California, United States, and part of the Los Angeles Combined Statistical Area. 

[[Romoland, California]]

Romoland is a census-designated place (CDP) in Riverside County, California, United States. The population was 1,684 at the 2010 census.

[[Svend Aage Rask]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Danish footballers, 2020 deaths

Svend Aage Rask (14 July 1935 – 29 June 2020) was a Danish footballer. During his club career he played for Boldklubben 1909. He earned 1 cap for the Denmark national football team. He was in the finals squad for the 1964 European Nations' Cup.

Rask died on 29 June 2020, aged 84.

[[Stay As You Are]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, 1970s romantic drama movies, Italian drama movies, Spanish movies, Movies directed by Alberto Lattuada

Stay As You Are (Così come sei), also known as Stay the Way You Are, is a 1978 Italian Spanish erotic drama movie directed by Alberto Lattuada and starring Marcello Mastroianni, Nastassja Kinski, Francisco Rabal, Mónica Randall, Ania Pieroni, Barbara De Rossi, José María Caffarel, Massimo Bonetti. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[VSS Vintorez]]

CATEGORIES: Rifles, Soviet Union, Russia

The VSS, also called the Vintorez, is a sniper rifle featuring a built-in suppresor (similar to that of the AS-Val) the weapon is loaded with heavy subsonic 9×39mm SP5 cartridges and armor-piercing SP6 cartridges. It was manufactured (created) by the Soviet company TsNIITochMash during the late 1980s. It is issued primarily to Spetsnaz units for secretive operations, a role made evident by its ability to be broken down for transport in a specially fitted case. 

[[M2 flamethrower]]

CATEGORIES: Incendiary weapons, United States

The M2 flamethrower was an American-made portable flamethrower that was used during World War II. It was the successor to the M1 and M1A1 flamethrowers. Although it could only shoot fire for around 7 seconds and the flame was only effective out to around 20–40 meters. However, with the arrival of flamethrower tanks, the need for flamethrower-carrying infantrymen to expose themselves to enemy fire was greatly reduced.

Though some M2s were sold off, the majority were scrapped (thrown away) when they were declared obsolete (uneeded).

[[Wilson (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 drama movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Henry King

Wilson is a 1944 American biographical drama movie directed by Henry King and starring Alexander Knox, Charles Coburn, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Thomas Mitchell, Ruth Nelson, Cedric Hardwicke, Vincent Price, Francis X. Bushman. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for 10 Oscars and won 5 Academy Awards in 1945.

[[Burslem]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Staffordshire, Stoke-on-Trent, Establishments in England

Burslem is one of the towns that is part of the city of Stoke-on-Trent in Staffordshire, England. The 2011 census revealed the ward had a population of 11,314 people.

Hanley, Tunstall, Fenton, Longton and Stoke-upon-Trent are the other towns that make up the city.

It is a very old town. The Domesday Book shows Burslem (then known as Bacardeslim) as a small farming hamlet. Even as far back as the late 12th century, there was a pottery industry in the town.

The Trent & Mersey Canal flows through the west and south of the town centre.

The football club Port Vale F.C. are based in the town. They play their home games at Vale Park.

Professional darts player Phil Taylor is from Burslem.

[[What's So Bad About Feeling Good?]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 comedy movies, 1960s fantasy movies, American fantasy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by George Seaton

What's So Bad About Feeling Good? is a 1968 American comedy movie directed by George Seaton and starring George Peppard, Mary Tyler Moore, Dom DeLuise, John McMartin, Charles Lane, Thelma Ritter. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and was a box office disappoint.

[[Agata Karczmarzewska]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, Polish volleyball players

Agata Karczmarzewska-Pura (born 27 June 1978) is a Polish volleyball player.

She played at the 2001 Women's European Volleyball Championship, 2004 FIVB World Grand Prix, and 2008 FIVB World Grand Prix.

She played for PTPS Nafta-Gaz Piła.

[[The Clown Murders]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 horror movies, Canadian horror movies

The Clown Murders is a 1976 Canadian horror movie directed by Martyn Burke and starring John Candy, Stephen Young, Lawrence Dane, Cec Linder, Al Waxman. It was distributed by Trans World Entertainment.

[[Yumika Yokoyama]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, 2008 deaths, Japanese sportspeople, Volleyball players, People from Beijing, Deaths from cancer

Yumika Yokoyama was a Japanese volleyball player.

[[Shaolin Chamber of Death]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 movies, 1970s action movies, Hong Kong movies

Shaolin Chamber of Death (少林木人巷) (Shao Lin mu ren xiang) is a 1976 Hong Kong action movie directed by Chen Chi-Hwa and starring Jackie Chan, Hwang Jang Lee, Yuen Biao, Lo Wei, Tien Miao, Chiang Kam. It was distributed by Lo Wei Productions.

[[Mihoko Tsutsui]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, Japanese sportspeople, Volleyball players

Mihoko Tsutsui (筒井 視穂子, born 6 December 1985) is a Japanese volleyball player. She played at the 2004 FIVB World Grand Prix and 2014 FIVB Women's Club World Championship.

She played for Hisamitsu Springs.

[[Verónica Contreras]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Peruvian people, Volleyball players

Verónica Contreras Flores (born 8 June 1977) is a Peruvian volleyball player.

She played at the 1996 Summer Olympics, 1994 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 2006 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 2006 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, 2007 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, and 2008 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup.

In 2012/13, she won the Liga Nacional Superior de Voleibol Femenino championship. She played for Regatas Lima, AD A Pinguela, CV Universidad César Vallejo, and CV Deportivo Géminis.

[[Moonraker (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 science fiction movies, 1970s action movies, 1970s spy movies, British science fiction movies, French science fiction movies, French action movies, American science fiction movies, American action movies, American spy movies, James Bond movies, Movies set in California, Movies set in France, Movies set in Venice, Movies set in South America, Movies directed by Lewis Gilbert, Roger Moore

Moonraker is a 1979 British French American science fiction spy action movie directed by Lewis Gilbert and is the 11th movie in the James Bond franchise. It stars Roger Moore, Lois Chiles, Michael Lonsdale, Richard Kiel, Corinne Cléry, Bernard Lee, Desmond Llewelyn, Geoffrey Keen, Lois Maxwell. It was distributed by United Artists and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1980. Shirley Bassey sings the title song of the movie.

[[Tatiana Smyrnidou]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, Greek sportspeople, Volleyball players, Living people

Tatiana Smyrnidou (born 21 June 1995) is a Greek volleyball player.

She played at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Filathlitikos Thessaloniki.

[[Claude Klee]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2017 deaths, French biologists, French biochemists

Claude B. Klee (born 1931, died April 3, 2017) was an French biochemist. She was awarded a 1991 Presidential Executive Rank Award. In 1992, she was elected to the National Academy of Medicine.

[[Fernanda Gritzbach]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Living people, Brazilian volleyball players, People from São Paulo

Fernanda Gritzbach (born 10 January 1984 in São Paulo) is a Brazilian volleyball player. She played at the 2003 Pan American Games and 2003 FIVB Volleyball Women's U20 World Championship.

She played for CV Logroño. In 2019-20, she was MVP of the Iberdrola League.

[[Walsall]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in the West Midlands (county), Market towns in England

Walsall is a market town in the county of the West Midlands, England. It is in the Metropolitan Borough of Walsall. It is historically part of Staffordshire. Its town centre is 8 miles (13 km) north-west of Birmingham and 6 miles (10 km) east of Wolverhampton. A 2011 census revealed that 67,594 people live in the town and 269,323 people live in the borough.

It is a very industrial town and was effected by the Industrial Revolution. The town used to have a large industry of making products such as saddles and chains.

Walsall has been majorly redeveloped and modernised since the 1970s and is still being constantly developed.

Barr Beacon is a hill located in Walsall. It is the highest point between itself and the Ural Mountains in Russia.

The town has a professional football club, Walsall FC. Their nickname is "The Saddlers" and they play their home games at the Bescot Stadium in the Bescot suburb of the town.

[[Tetyana Budko]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Ukrainian volleyball players, Living people

Tetyana Budko (born 1984) is a Ukrainian volleyball player. She played at the 2003 Women's European Volleyball Championship, 2002/2003 European Cups, 2004/2005 European Championships, and 2003 FIVB Women's U20 World Championship.

[[Yuliya Bogmatser]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Ukrainian volleyball players, Living people

Yuliya Bogmatser (born 3 June 1984 in Zaporizhia) is a Ukrainian volleyball player. She played at the 2002 Women's Junior European Volleyball Championship, winning a silver medal, 2003 Women's European Volleyball Championship, and 2010 FIVB Women's World Championships.

She was best setter in the Ukrainian Superliga in 2004/05 and in 2005/06.

[[List of data references for chemical elements]]

CATEGORIES: Chemical elements

The List of data references for chemical elements is divided into datasheets that give values for many properties of the elements, together with various references. Each datasheet is sequenced by atomic number.

[[Oxygen-16]]

CATEGORIES: Isotopes

Oxygen-16 (16O) is a stable isotope of oxygen, having 8 neutrons and 8 protons in its nucleus. 

[[Spetsnaz]]

CATEGORIES: Special Forces

Spetsnaz is an umbrella term (used for many different things) for special forces in Russian language and is used in numerous post-Soviet states.

Historically, the term meant a special operations units controlled by the main military intelligence service GRU (Spetsnaz GRU). It also describes task forces of other ministries (such as the Ministry of Internal Affairs' ODON and Ministry of Emergency Situations' special rescue unit) in post-Soviet countries. Russian special forces wear different berets depending on the branch of the armed forces they belong to.

As Spetsnaz is a Russian term, it mostly means the special forces of Russia, but other post-Soviet states often refer to their special forces units by the name as well, since these nations also got their special purpose units from the old Soviet security agencies.

[[Oxygen-17]]

CATEGORIES: Isotopes

Oxygen-17 (17O) is a low-abundance, natural, stable isotope of oxygen (0.0373% in seawater; it is about twice as common as deuterium).

[[Oxygen-18]]

CATEGORIES: Isotopes

Oxygen-18 (18, Ω) is a natural, stable isotope of oxygen and one of the environmental isotopes.

[[Madeley, Shropshire]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Shropshire, Civil parishes in Shropshire

Madeley is a town and civil parish in Shropshire, England. It is in the borough of Telford and Wrekin and is now part of the new town of Telford. In 2001, the town had a population of 17,935 people.

Madeley is recorded in the Domesday Book as a small settlement.

A part of the Ironbridge Gorge, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is in the civil parish.

[[Bob the Builder (2015 TV series)]]

CATEGORIES:  2015 television series debuts,  2018 television series endings

Bob the Builder is a CGI animated children's television series and a reboot of the British-American animated television show Bob the Builder. It was first broadcast in the United Kingdom on Channel 5, beginning on 1 September 2015 and PBS Kids in the United States in 14 November. The series ran for three seasons until 30 December 2018.

This show also has a feature length special called Mega Machines which was released in 2017.

A next Bob the Builder series is currently yet to be announced.

[[Olga Pavlova]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, Ukrainian volleyball players

Olga Pavlova (born 4 March 1969) is a Ukrainian volleyball player. She represented Ukraine during the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.

[[Wellington, Shropshire]]

CATEGORIES: Market towns in Shropshire, Civil parishes in Shropshire

Wellington is a market town and civil parish in Shropshire, England. It is in the borough of Telford and Wrekin and forms part of the new town of Telford. It is 3.5 miles (5.5 km) northwest of central Telford and 12 miles (19 km) east of Shrewsbury. The 2011 census revealed that the town has a population of 25,554 people.

It became part of the new town of Telford in 1968.

The town's population makes it the third largest town in Shropshire, behind Telford and Shrewsbury.

The Wrekin hill is 3.5 miles southwest of the town.

The town has a railway station on the Wolverhampton–Shrewsbury line. Passengers can get direct trains to Shrewsbury, Wolverhampton, Birmingham, London and parts of Wales.

The New Bucks Head, the home stadium of football club A.F.C. Telford United, is located in Wellington.

[[Stoke on Tern]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Shropshire, Civil parishes in Shropshire

Stoke on Tern is a village in Shropshire, England. It is in the civil parish of Stoke upon Tern, next to the River Tern. 

It is near to the border with Staffordshire. In the 2011 census, the civil parish had a population of 2,034 people. The small villages of Stoke Heath, Ollerton, Eaton upon Tern and Wistanswick are also in the parish.

The village is 6.5 miles (10.5 km) south-west of the centre of Market Drayton and is around half way between Market Drayton and Telford. The village of Hodnet is 2.6 miles (4.2 km) to the west.

The village has a church and a primary school.

[[Llanymynech]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Shropshire, Villages in Powys

Llanymynech is a village in Shropshire, England and Powys, Wales. It is in the civil parish of Llanymynech and Pant, next to the River Vyrnwy.

It is located 17.4 miles north-west of Shrewsbury, Shropshire's county town and 9 miles (14 km) north of the Welsh town of Welshpool. It straddles the Welsh border. Some parts of the village, such as the golf course, are located in Wales. Two of the village's three pubs are entirely in England and the third is entirely in Wales.

The village's name is "Church of the Monks" in Welsh.

Shortly to the north of the village is the village of Pant. Further north is the market town of Oswestry.

The village has an amateur football club, Llanymynech FC.

[[Olena Kryvonossova]]

Olena Kryvonossova (born 24 June 1972) is a Ukrainian volleyball player. She represented Ukraine during the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.

[[Yuliya Buyeva]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, Ukrainian volleyball players

Yuliya Buyeva (born December 24, 1975) is a Ukrainian volleyball player. She represented Ukraine during the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. She played for Universidad Granada, BBSC Berlin, Beşiktaş, and Universidad de Burgos.

[[Lamborghini LM001]]

CATEGORIES: Lamborghini automobiles

The Lamborghini LM001 is an off-road vehicle made by Lamborghini in 1981. It was first revealed at the 1981 Geneva Auto Show along with the new-at-the-time Lamborghini Jalpa. 

The LM001 was made for military use, but only one prototype was ever made. This was because the rear-engine design made the car handle poorly.

[[A12 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A12 is a short autoroute (motorway) in France. It used to be called the Autoroute de Bretagne (Autoroute of Brittany) in French. It is to the west of Paris. It goes between the A13 and the N10. The autoroute is about 8.5 long.

[[Mariya Aleksandrova]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Ukrainian volleyball players, Living people

Mariya Aleksandrova (born 7 April 1974) is a Ukrainian volleyball player.

She represented Ukraine during the 2001 Women's European Volleyball Championship.

She played for SVS Post Schwechat and Schweriner SC.

[[Sanmiguelia]]

CATEGORIES: Magnoliopsida, Fossil plants, Extinct plants

Sanmiguelia is a  genus of the fossil plants, possible may be among the earliest of angiosperms. It was determined on the basis its  imprints of  palm-shaped leaves originated from Triassic   geological period (251 to 199.6 million years ago). They were found in rocks  from Colorado . 

The leaves were ellipsoidal and wrinkled, up to 40 cm long and 25 cm wide, and were at the apex of a tapered or spindle-shaped stem. 

According to these data, it belonged to a possible  family flowering plants  Sanmigueliaceae , unknown  order, in class Magnoliopsida,  division Tracheophyta.

[[Incitatus]]

CATEGORIES: Horses, Ancient Rome

Incitatus was Emperor Caligula's favorite horse.  He lived in Ancient Rome around 40 c.e.  His name means "fast-moving."

There is a story that Caligula made his horse a senator, but it is probably not true.  According to historian Mary Beard, no ancient historian who was alive at the same time as Caligula ever said Caligula really made Incitatus a senator, and it is likely that he only told a joke about doing it.

Ancient historians do say Caligula gave his horse many gifts.  In 121 c.e., in his book The Twelve Caesars, the historian Suetonius says of Incitatus: "Besides a stall of marble, a manger of ivory, purple blankets and a collar of precious stones, he even gave this horse a house, a troop of slaves and furniture, for the more elegant entertainment of the guests invited in his name; and it is also said that he planned to make him consul."

[[Lamborghini Cheetah]]

CATEGORIES: Lamborghini automobiles, 1970s automobiles

The Lamborghini Cheetah is an off-road prototype that was made by Lamborghini in 1977.

[[Boston River]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Uruguay, 1930s establishments in South America, 1939 establishments, Uruguayan football clubs, Montevideo

Boston River is a football club which plays in Montevideo, Uruguay. It was founded in 1939.

The club has a historic season in 2017 when the qualified for the Copa Sudamericana for the first time ever. They were eliminated by Paraguayan club Cerro Porteno in the second round. The following season they also qualified for the same cup, this time being eliminated by Banfield in the same round, after beating Jaguares de Cordoba 4-2 on aggregate. 

[[Telford and Wrekin]]

CATEGORIES: Unitary authority districts of England, Shropshire

Telford and Wrekin is a unitary authority district and borough in the West Midlands of England. It is part of the ceremonial county of Shropshire. It borders Staffordshire.

The district was created in 1974 and was called The Wrekin.

It is the only seperate unitary authority in Shropshire. It shares its Fire and Rescue Service and Community Health with the rest of the county.

The biggest town in the borough is Telford. The borough also includes the towns of Wellington, Shifnal, Bridgnorth and Newport.

[[Shawbury]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Shropshire, Civil parishes in Shropshire

Shawbury is a village and civil parish in Shropshire, England. It is 8.4 miles (13.5 km) north east of Shrewsbury, the county town, 11.5 miles (18.5 km) north west of Telford and 163 miles (262 km) north west of London. The 2011 census revealed the parish had 2,872 residents.

The village is recorded in the 1085 Domesday Book. In the book, it is called Sawesberie. 

The A53 between Shrewsbury and Market Drayton goes through the village.

The village has a Co-operative shop, a pub, a church, a chip shop and a Chinese takeaway.

It is home to RAF Shawbury, a Royal Air Force base.

[[Von Ryan's Express]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 movies, 1960s war movies, 1960s adventure movies, American adventure movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Mark Robson, Movies based on books

Von Ryan's Express is a 1965 American World War II adventure movie directed by Mark Robson and based on the novel of the same name by David Westheimer. It stars Frank Sinatra, Trevor Howard, Raffaella Carrà, Brad Dexter, Sergio Fantoni, John Leyton, James Brolin, Edward Mulhare, Wolfgang Preiss, Vito Scotti and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1966.

[[Ivan Utrobin]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Soviet Olympic medalists, Olympic bronze medalists, Skiers

Ivan Stepanovich Utrobin (Иван Степанович Утробин) (March 10, 1934 – June 25, 2020) was a Soviet cross-country skier. He competed during the early 1960s, training at VSS Trud in Moscow Oblast. He earned a bronze medal in the 4 x 10 km event at 1964 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck. 

Utrobin died on June 25, 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Lamborghini 350 GT]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s automobiles, Lamborghini automobiles, Sports cars

The Lamborghini 350 GT is a sports car made by Lamborghini from 1964 to 1966. It is the first road car made by Lamborghini. The 350 GT was based off the Lamborghini 350GTV prototype. Both cars used a 3.5-liter V12 engine. 

The Lamborghini 400 GT was the successor to the 350 GT.

[[Rudolfo Anaya]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, American novelists, American political writers, American poets, American educators, American playwrights, Writers from Albuquerque, New Mexico

Rudolfo Anaya (October 30, 1937 – June 28, 2020) was an American author, poet, educator and playwright. He was best known for his 1972 novel Bless Me, Ultima. Anaya was thought to be one of the founders of Chicano literature. He was born in Pastura, New Mexico.

Anaya died on June 28, 2020 at his home in Albuquerque, New Mexico at the age of 82.

[[Pastura, New Mexico]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in New Mexico, Census-designated places in New Mexico

Pastura is a small unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) in Guadalupe County, New Mexico, United States, approximately halfway between Santa Rosa and Vaughn. As of the 2010 census it had a population of 23.

[[Vaughn, New Mexico]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New Mexico

Vaughn is a town in Guadalupe County, New Mexico, United States. The population was 446 at the 2010 census. 

[[Klaus Francke]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, German politicians, People from Hamburg

Klaus Francke (17 July 1936 – 28 June 2020) was a German politician. He was a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). Francke was a member of the German Bundestag from 1976 to 1998 and again from 2001 to 2002. He was born in Hamburg.

Francke died on 28 June 2020 in Hamburg, aged 83.

[[Louis Mahoney]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, British movie actors, British television actors, British stage actors, British activists, Trade unionists, Actors from London

Louis Felix Danner Mahoney (8 September 1938 – 28 June 2020) was a Gambian-born British actor. He was born in The Gambia. He was an anti-racist activist. He represented African-Asian members on the council of the actors'union, Equity. He became Vice President between 1994 and 1996. Mahoney was known for his multiple roles on Doctor Who and as Brother Paulo in Omen III: The Final Conflict. He also appeared in Captain Phillips.

Mahoney died on 28 June 2020 in London, aged 81.

[[Bode Akindele]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Nigerian businesspeople

Chief Bode Akindele (2 June 1932 – 29 June 2020) was a Nigerian billionaire businessman. According to The Daily Telegraph, he was worth about $1.19 billion. He was the owner and Chairman of Madandola group of companies. He was born in Oyo, Oyo.

Akindele died on 29 June 2020 at his home in Lagos, aged 88.

[[Oyo, Oyo]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Nigeria

Oyo is an ancient city in Oyo State, Nigeria. It was founded as the capital of the historic Oyo empire in the 1830.

[[Efraín Barquero]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from COPD, Chilean poets

Efraín Barquero (3 May 1931 – 29 June 2020) was a Chilean poet. He won the Chilean National Prize for Literature in 2008. He worked in Colombia during the government of Salvador Allende. In France he wrote A deshora  between 1979 and 1985, which was later published in Chile in 1992. During this time he also wrote Mujeres de oscuro and El viejo y el niño.

Barquero died in Santiago de Chile on 29 June 2020 from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, aged 89.

[[Albert Sulon]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian footballers

Albert Sulon (3 April 1938 – 29 June 2020) was a Belgian footballer. He played as a defender. Sulon played for RFC Liège, UR Namur, RES Jamboise and Tilleur FC. He also earned 6 caps for the Belgian national team between 1965 and 1967.

Sulon died on 29 June 2020, aged 82.

[[Ivo Banac]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Croatian writers, Croatian politicians, American historians

Ivo Banac (iːʋo baːnats; 1 March 1947 – 30 June 2020) was a Croatian-American historian. He was a professor of European history at Yale University. He was a politician of the former Liberal Party in Croatia. Banac was a consultant for the Bosnian Institute. In 1990, he became a member of the Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts. He was President of the Liberal Party (2003–2004) and MP (2003–2008).

Banac died on 30 June 2020, aged 73.

[[Tim Brooks (wrestler)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Texas, American professional wrestlers, Sportspeople from Dallas, Texas

Timothy Paul Brooks (December 4, 1947 – June 30, 2020) was an American professional wrestler. He was better-known by his ring name "Killer" Tim Brooks. He competed in North American regional promotions such as in the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA), Pacific Northwest Wrestling (PNW) World Wrestling Council and World Class Championship Wrestling (WCCW) and Southwest Championship Wrestling (SWCW) during the 1970s and 1980s. Brooks was born in Dallas, Texas.

Brooks died on June 30, 2020 at his home in Waxahachie, Texas from cancer at the age of 72.

[[Our Huge Adventure]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 movies, 2005 animated movies, 2000s adventure movies, 2000s fantasy movies, 2000s musical movies, American animated movies, American adventure movies, American fantasy movies, American musical movies, Disney animated movies

Our Huge Adventure (stylized as OUR BIG Huge ADVENTURE) is an American animated musical adventure movie. It was released on August 23, 2005 by Walt Disney Home Entertainment and Playhouse Disney. It was followed by the TV series Little Einsteins.

[[Plains brown tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The plains brown tree frog, plain tree frog or Victoria frog (Litoria paraewingi) is a frog from Australia. It lives in southern Australia just north of Melbourne, in Victoria and New South Wales.

The adult male is 2.1 to 2.8 cm long and the adult female is 3.4 to 3.6 cm long.  It is pale brown in colour with a stripe from its nose over its eyes and down its body.  Parts of its legs are pale yellow or orange.  It looks very similar to the brown tree frog.

This frog can live in forests or grasslands.  It lives in bodies of water that are still or slow-flowing, like creeks, ditches, lakes, and slow parts of rivers.

The plains brown tree frog is closely related to the brown tree frog, enough that they can have babies together when they meet in the wild, though this is rare.  Scientists studied the nuclear DNA and mitochondrial DNA of hybrid frogs and they found that it was male plains brown tree frogs mating with female brown tree frogs more than half the time.

They lay eggs on underwater plants.

[[Salma Lakhani]]

CATEGORIES: People from Edmonton, Politicians from Alberta, Canadian businesspeople, Canadian philanthropists, Muslims

Salma Lakhani is a Canadian businessperson and philanthropist. She will be the next Lieutenant Governor of Alberta. She will also be the first Muslim Lieutenant Governor in Canada.

[[Kimberly Exner]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Canadian volleyball players

Kimberly Exner (born 16 July 1977) is a Canadian volleyball player. She is part of the Canadian women's national volleyball team. She competed at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Eastern Washington University's women's volleyball team.

[[Maite Perroni]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican voice actors, Mexican singer-songwriters, Dancers, Mexican models, Actors from Mexico City, Writers from Mexico City, Singers from Mexico City

Maite Perroni Beorlegui (born March 9, 1983) is a Mexican actress, singer-songwriter, dancer and model. She is best known for starring in the Mexican telenovela Rebelde.

[[Rebelde]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 television series debuts, 2006 television series endings, Mexican television series

Rebelde (English: Rebel) is a Mexican telenovela produced by Televisa and created by Cris Morena. It is a remake of the Argentine telenovela Rebelde Way created for the Mexican audience. The series aired on Canal de las Estrellas from October 4, 2004, to June 2, 2006. Rebelde was replaced in June 2006 with Televisa's series Código Postal.

The show is set at the Elite Way School, a private boarding high school in Mexico City with a major plot line revolving around a group of students forming a pop band. 

[[Gernot Endemann]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, German movie actors, German television actors, People from Essen

Gernot Endemann (24 June 1942 – 29 June 2020) was a German actor. He was at one time married to the French actress Jocelyne Boisseau. His career began in 1965. Endemann was born in Essen, Germany. 

He was known for his roles in Angels of the Street (1969), Willi Manages The Whole Thing (1972), Shout at the Devil (1976), Mandara (1983) and Der Schatz im Niemandsland (1987). He also played Horsch in the German version of Sesame Street.

Endemann died on 29 June 2020 in Hanover, Germany at the age of 77.

[[Rafał Trzaskowski]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Mayors of Warsaw, Political scientists

Rafał Kazimierz Trzaskowski (pronounced Ra Tsha t; born 17 January 1972) is a Polish politician. In November 2018, he became the Mayor of Warsaw. He is also a political scientist.

In May 2020, Trzaskowski became the Civic Platform's candidate for Presidency of Poland in the presidential election. He lost the election to incumbent President Andrzej Duda.

[[Winnipeg Beach]]

Winnipeg Beach is a beach in the southwestern part of Winnipeg and it is fun for friends and family. There is also an amusement park nearby. It is also one of the many landmark for tourists and visitors. Winnipeg Beach is not only a beach, it is also a town.

[[Samsung Galaxy Note 20]]

CATEGORIES: Samsung mobile phones, Mobile phones with multiple rear cameras, Mobile phones with 4K video recording

The Samsung Galaxy Note 20 is an  line of Android-based phablets designed, developed, to be produced and it was  marketed by Samsung Electronics for its Samsung Galaxy Note series, succeeding the Samsung Galaxy Note 10 series. It is released on 5 August 2020 alongside the Samsung Galaxy Fold 2 during Samsung's Unpacked Event with shipment expected to start on 20 August 2020.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the release of the phablets will only be streamed online via Samsung's online platforms and channels.June 2020

[[Elmer McCurdy]]

CATEGORIES: 1880 births, 1911 deaths, Deaths by firearm in the United States, American criminals, People from Maine, People from Oklahoma

Elmer J. McCurdy (January 1, 1880 – October 7, 1911) was an American bank and train robber. He was killed in a shoot-out with police after robbing a train in Oklahoma in October 1911. 

[[Mannequin]]

CATEGORIES: Dolls

A mannequin (also called a manikin, dummy, lay figure or dress form) is a doll used by artists, tailors, dressmakers, windowdressers and others especially to display or fit clothing. 

During the 1950s, mannequins were used in nuclear tests to help show the effects of nuclear weapons on humans.

[[Washington, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine

Washington, officially the Town of Washington, is a town in Knox County, Maine. The population was 1,527 at the 2010 United States Census.

[[Osage Hills]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Oklahoma

The Osage Hills is a hilly area in Oklahoma, commonly known as The Osage.  The name refers to the broad rolling hills and rolling tallgrass prairie and Cross Timbers in Osage County, Oklahoma.

[[Croatian Parliament]]

CATEGORIES: Croatia, National legislatures

The Croatian Parliament (Hrvatski sabor) or the Sabor is the unicameral representative body of the citizens of the Republic of Croatia.

It is Croatia's legislature. Under the terms of the Croatian Constitution, the Sabor represents the people and is vested with legislative power. The Sabor is made up of 151 members elected to a four-year term.

[[Aleksandr Kabanov]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Russian water polo players, Olympic gold medalists, Water polo coaches

Aleksandr Sergeyevich Kabanov (Александр Серге́евич Кабанов, 11 June 1948 – 30 June 2020) was a Russian water polo player and head coach of the Russian water polo team. He was one of a few sportspeople who won Olympic medals in water polo as players and head coaches. He won two gold medals at the 1972 and 1980 Olympics.

Kabanov died on 30 June 2020, aged 72.

[[2020 Polish presidential election]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 elections in Europe, 21st century in Poland, June 2020 events, July 2020 events, Politics of Poland

The 2020 Polish presidential elections were due to be held on 10 May 2020, but were postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 

On 3 June 2020, the Marshal of the Sejm, Elżbieta Witek, ordered the first round of the election to be held on 28 June 2020 and scheduled the second round, on 12 July 2020.

The conservative incumbent president Andrzej Duda is eligible for reelection.

Duda faced off in the second round against Civic Platform Candidate, Mayor of Warsaw Rafał Trzaskowski after first round results showed Duda with 43.5% of the vote and Trzaskowski with 30.5%. In the second round, Duda won re-election after winning 51% of the vote to Trzaskowski's 48%.

[[Lazarus Chakwera]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Presidents of Malawi, Current national leaders, Theologians

Lazarus McCarthy Chakwera (born 5 April 1955) is a Malawian theologian and politician. He became the 6th President of Malawi in June 2020. He has been leader of the Malawi Congress Party since 2013. He was President of the Malawi Assemblies of God from 1989 to 14 May 2013.

Chakwera obtained a Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy from the University of Malawi in 1977. He studied theology and obtained an Honors BA from the University of Limpopo in South Africa, then a Masters from the University of South Africa in 1991. In 2000, he obtained a doctorate from Trinity International University, in the USA.

[[The Queen of Spades (1982 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 drama movies, Russian movies

The Queen of Spades (Pikovaya dama) is a 1982 Russian drama movie directed by Igor Maslennikov and is the sixth adaption of the 1834 short story of the same name by Alexander Pushkin. It stars Alla Demidova, Viktor Proskurin, Irina Dymchenko, Elena Gogoleva.

[[I Ought to Be in Pictures (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Herbert Ross

I Ought to Be in Pictures is a 1982 American comedy drama movie directed by Herbert Ross and based on the 1980 play of the same name by Neil Simon. It stars Walter Matthau, Ann-Margaret, Dinah Manoff, Lance Guest, Larry Barton, David Faustino, Martin Ferrero, Michael Dudikoff and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Blank Slate]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 books, Psychology

The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature is a popular 2002 book by the psychologist Steven Pinker. The author makes a case against tabula rasa (people who believe we are all born with no built in  mental content). The book was voted for the 2003 Aventis Prizes and was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize.

[[Avanti West Coast]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s establishments in the United Kingdom, 2019 establishments in Europe, Train operating companies, Railway companies of the United Kingdom

Avanti West Coast is a British train operating company. It operates the West Coast Partnership franchise and has done since 8 December 2019, where it took over from Virgin Trains. 

The company is owned by Scottish-based company FirstGroup and Italian company Trenitalia.

"Avanti" means "Forward" in Italian.

They currently operate services mainly up the West Coast Main Line. These services are between London, England's capital city, and various other towns and cities around Great Britain. These include direct trains to Manchester, Liverpool, Birmingham, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Wolverhampton, Shrewsbury, Chester and Blackpool. They also operate services between London and Holyhead, Wrexham or Bangor in North Wales.

There are currently plans for future services to Walsall, Llandudno Junction and the village of Gobowen in Shropshire from 2022.

Journeys with Avanti are very popular with commuters as the trains do not call at every station and only stop at some stations along their route. However, due to this, tickets for travel with them can be expensive.

[[Disneyland Paris]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in France, 1992 establishments in Europe, Disney theme parks, Buildings and structures in France, Île-de-France

Disneyland Paris, formerly Euro Disney Resort, is a resort near Paris, France. It is in Chessy, Seine-et-Marne.

[[Island of Love]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies set in islands

Island of Love is a 1963 American comedy movie directed by Morton DaCosta and starring Robert Preston, Tony Randall, Giorgia Moll, Walter Matthau, Peter Mamakos, Titos Vandis, Michael Constantine. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Holyhead]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Anglesey

Holyhead (Caergybi) is the largest town and community on the Isle of Anglesey, Wales. The town is an important port that serves Ireland. The 2011 census found that the town had 11,431 residents.

The town's name in Welsh means "Cybi's fort".

It used to have a large aluminium smelting industry, using the large smelters on the outskirts of the town. However, the aluminium company closed in September 2009.

The Anglesey Coastal Path starts and finishes here.

[[International Chamber of Commerce]]

CATEGORIES: International organizations

The International Chamber of Commerce (ICC; French: Chambre de commerce internationale) is the largest, most representative business organization in the world. Its over 45 million members in over 100 countries. ICC has three main activities: rule setting, dispute resolution, and policy advocacy. 

ICC supports the work of the United Nations, the World Trade Organization, and many other intergovernmental bodies, both international and regional, such as G20 on behalf of international business.

[[G20]]

CATEGORIES: International organizations

The G20 (or Group of Twenty) is an international forum for the governments and central bank governors from 20* countries and the European Union (EU). It was founded in 1999. The goal is to promote international financial stability. 

Since the November 2011 Cannes summit, G20 summits have been held annually.

[[Latifur Rahman (businessman)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s births, 2020 deaths, Bangladeshi businesspeople

Latifur Rahman (1944/1945 – 1 July 2020) was a Bangladeshi businessman. From 2014 to 2017, he was a member of the International Chamber of Commerce. He was the chairman of Transcom Group.

Rahman died from an illness at his home in the Comilla District, Bangladesh at the age of 75.

[[Ransom (1975 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 thriller movies, British thriller movies

Ransom is a 1974 British thriller movie directed by Caspar Wrede and starring Sean Connery, Ian McShane, Christopher Ellison, Jeffry Wickham, Isabel Dean, Robert Harris. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Whiteville, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in North Carolina, County seats in North Carolina

Whiteville is a city in Columbus County, North Carolina, United States. The population was 5,394 at the 2010 census. It is the largest city in Columbus County and is the county seat.

[[Eva Clayton]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, United States representatives from North Carolina, People from Savannah, Georgia, Politicians from Georgia (U.S. state), US Democratic Party politicians

Eva McPherson Clayton (born September 16, 1934) is an American Democratic politician. When she was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1992, Clayton became the first African American to represent North Carolina in the House since 1898. She retired from politics in 2003.

[[Cumberland County, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: 1750s establishments in North Carolina, 1754 establishments, North Carolina counties

Cumberland County is a county located in the U.S. state of North Carolina. As of the 2010 census, the population was 319,431, making it the fifth-most populous county in North Carolina. Its county seat is Fayetteville.

[[G. K. Butterfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, United States representatives from North Carolina, American civil rights activists, American lawyers, US Democratic Party politicians

George Kenneth Butterfield Jr. (born April 27, 1947) is an American politician. In 2004, he was elected to the U.S. Representative for North Carolina's 1st congressional district. He is a member of the Democratic Party.

Butterfield was appointed to be an Associate Justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court by Governor Mike Easley in 2001. He is a member of the Congressional Black Caucus and was its chair from 2015 to 2017.

[[Wilson County, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: 1850s establishments in North Carolina, 1855 establishments in the United States, North Carolina counties

Wilson County is a county located in the U.S. state of North Carolina. As of the 2010 Census, the population was 81,234. The county seat is Wilson.

[[Ida (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2013 drama movies, Polish movies, Danish movies, French drama movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by Paweł Pawlikowski

Ida is a 2013 Polish Danish French British drama movie directed by Paweł Pawlikowski and starring Agata Kulesza, Agata Trzebuchowska, Dawid Ogrodnik, Jerzy Trela. It was distributed by Solopan and was nominated for 2 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 2015.

[[Mike Easley]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Governors of North Carolina, American lawyers, American Roman Catholics, US Democratic Party politicians, Businesspeople from North Carolina

Michael Francis Easley (born March 23, 1950) is an American lawyer and politician. He was the 72nd Governor of the U.S. state of North Carolina from January 2001 to January 2009. He is the first 

He is a member of the Democratic Party. Easley was North Carolina's second Catholic governor.

[[West Mercia Police]]

CATEGORIES: Law enforcement agencies of the United Kingdom, 1967 establishments in Europe, 1960s establishments in England

West Mercia Police is a territorial police service that polices Herefordshire, Shropshire and Worcestershire. It was known as West Mercia Constabulary until it was renamed in 2009. Its name comes from the area it polices formerly being the western part of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Mercia.

It was formed on 1 October 1967. It was created when Worcestershire Constabulary, Herefordshire Constabulary, Shropshire Constabulary, and Worcester City Police merged together.

It is the fourth largest police service in England and Wales.

The service has around 2,000 police officers, 200 police community support officers, 1,500 police staff, and 400 special officers.

Their headquarters is at Hindlip Hall on the outskirts of the city of Worcester.

[[The Changeling (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 horror movies, Canadian horror movies, Movies directed by Peter Medak

The Changeling is a 1980 Canadian horror movie directed by Peter Medak and starring George C. Scott, Trish Van Devere, Melvyn Douglas, John Colicos, Jean Marsh, Roberta Maxwell. It was distributed by ITC Entertainment.

[[RFC Liège]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century establishments in Belgium, 1892 establishments in Europe, Belgian football clubs, Liège

Royal Football Club de Liège (RFC Liège) is a Belgian football club from the city of Liège. It currently plays in the Belgian First Amateur Division. The club was also known for being 'homeless' between 1995 and 2015, but is now playing on its own ground in Rocourt. 

[[Utz]]

Utz is a 1992 German Italian British drama movie directed by George Sluizer and based on the 1988 novel of the same name by Bruce Chatwin. It stars Armin Mueller-Stahl, Brenda Fricker, Peter Riegert, Paul Scofield and was distributed by First Run Pictures.
